Geographic coordinates: 49 00 N, 32 00 E

Map references: Commonwealth of Independent States

Area:
total: 603,700 sq km

Maritime claims:
continental shelf: 200-m or to the depth of exploitation
exclusive economic zone: 200 nm
territorial sea: 12 nm

Climate: temperate continental; Mediterranean only on the southern Crimean coast; precipitation disproportionately distributed, highest in west and north, lesser in east and southeast; winters vary from cool along the Black Sea to cold farther inland; summers are warm across the greater part of the country, hot in the south

Terrain: most of Ukraine consists of fertile plains (steppes) and plateaus, mountains being found only in the west (the Carpathians), and in the Crimean Peninsula in the extreme south

Elevation extremes:
lowest point: Black Sea 0 m
highest point: Hora Hoverla 2,061 m

Natural resources: iron ore, coal, manganese, natural gas, oil, salt, sulfur, graphite, titanium, magnesium, kaolin, nickel, mercury, timber, arable land

forests and woodland: 18%
other: 9% (1993 est.)

Irrigated land: 26,050 sq km (1993 est.)

Natural hazards: NA

Environment - current issues: inadequate supplies of potable water; air and water pollution; deforestation; radiation contamination in the northeast from 1986 accident at Chornobyl' Nuclear Power Plant

Environment - international agreements:
party to: Air Pollution, Air Pollution-Nitrogen Oxides, Air Pollution-Sulphur 85, Antarctic Treaty, Biodiversity, Climate Change, Endangered Species, Environmental Modification, Hazardous Wastes, Law of the Sea, Marine Dumping, Nuclear Test Ban, Ozone Layer Protection, Ship Pollution, Wetlands

 '''[[Geographic coordinates]]:''' {{coor dm|49|00|N|32|00|E|type:country}}
 
+== Land ==
+
 The total geographic area of Ukraine is 603,700 square kilometers. The land border of Ukraine is, in total, 4558 kilometers. It is bordered by [[Belarus]] (891km), [[Hungary]] (103km), [[Moldova]] (939km), [[Poland]] (428km), [[Romania]](169km on the south, 362km on the west), [[Russia]] (1576km) and [[Slovakia]] (90km). Ukraine is also bordered by 2782 kilometers of coastline. 
+
+Most of Ukraine consists of fertile plains (steppes) and plateaus, mountains being found only in the west (the Carpathians), and in the [[Crimea]]n Peninsula in the extreme south. The highest elevation in Ukraine is recorded at [[Hora Hoverla]], at 2061m. In terms of land use, 58% of Ukraine is considered arable land; 2% is used for permanent crops, 13% for permanent pastures, 18% is forests and woodland and 9% is other.
+
+== Climate ==
 
 Ukraine has a temperate continental climate; [[Mediterranean]] only on the southern Crimean coast. Precipitation in Ukraine is disproportionately distributed, highest in west and north and less in east and southeast. Winters vary from cool along the Black Sea to cold farther inland; summers are warm across the greater part of the country,very hot in the south
 
-Most of Ukraine consists of fertile plains (steppes) and plateaus, mountains being found only in the west (the Carpathians), and in the [[Crimea]]n Peninsula in the extreme south. The highest elevation in Ukraine is recorded at [[Hora Hoverla]], at 2061m. In terms of land use, 58% of Ukraine is considered arable land; 2% is used for permanent crops, 13% for permanent pastures, 18% is forests and woodland and 9% is other.
+== Natural resources ==
 
 Significant natural resources in the Ukraine include: iron ore, coal, manganese, natural gas, oil, salt, sulfur, graphite, titanium, magnesium, kaolin, nickel, mercury, timber, arable land
+
+== Environmental issues ==
 
 Significant environmental issues facing Ukraine include inadequate supplies of potable water; air and water pollution; deforestation; radiation contamination in the northeast from [[Chernobyl accident|1986 accident]] at [[Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant|Chornobyl (Chernobyl) Nuclear Power Plant]].

+Bigger part of Ukraine territory could be characterized as being regular plains (the average height above the sea level is 175m (~550 feet)), the mountains only are located to the west and to its extreme south. Wide spaces of the country's plains that constitute the south-western part of the [[East European Plain]] for its relief are not all the same. One may outline numerous highlands and lowlands establishment of which is caused mostly by the uneven crystallized base of the [[East European craton]]. Highlands mainly are associated with the [[Ukrainian Shield|Ukrainian crystallized massif]].

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -37,6 +37,7 @@
 Bigger part of Ukraine territory could be characterized as being regular plains (the average height above the sea level is 175 m (550 feet), the mountains only are located to the west and to its extreme south. Wide spaces of the country's plains that constitute the south-western part of the [[East European Plain]] for its relief are not all the same. One may outline numerous highlands and lowlands establishment of which is caused mostly by the uneven crystallized base of the [[East European craton]]. Highlands mainly are associated with the [[Ukrainian Shield|Ukrainian crystallized massif]].
 
 == Climate ==
+''See also: [[Ukraine#Climate|Climate of Ukraine]]''
 
 Ukraine has a temperate continental climate; [[Mediterranean]] only on the southern Crimean coast. Precipitation in Ukraine is disproportionately distributed, highest in west and north and less in east and southeast. Winters vary from cool along the Black Sea to cold farther inland; summers are warm across the greater part of the country, very hot in the south.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -5,7 +5,7 @@
 
 [[Ukraine]] is the second-largest country in Europe. Its geography varies significantly depending on regions. 
 
-==Geographic Location==
+==Geographic Location== [[Emma]]
 It has a strategic position in [[Eastern Europe]], bordering the [[Black Sea]] in the south,  [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]] and [[Hungary]] in the west, [[Belarus]] in the north, [[Moldova]] and [[Romania]] in the south-west and [[Russia]] in the east. The northern part of the [[Carpathian Mountains]] (highest peak [[Hoverla]], 2061 m) reaches into Ukraine in the western part of the country, but most of its area is taken up by the [[steppe]] north of the Black Sea, divided by the [[Dnieper|Dnipro]], which traverses Ukraine north to south, joining the Black Sea west of the [[Crimea]], near the mouths of the [[Southern Bug|Bug]] and the [[Dniester|Dnister]]. The border with Russia runs through the [[Sea of Azov]].
 
 '''[[Geographic coordinates]]:''' {{coord|49|00|N|32|00|E|type:country}}

--- 
+++ 
@@ -22,19 +22,19 @@
 
 [[Ukraine]] is the second-largest country in Europe. Its geography varies significantly depending on regions. 
 
-==Geographic Location==
+==Geographic location==
 It has a strategic position in [[Eastern Europe]], bordering the [[Black Sea]] in the south,  [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]] and [[Hungary]] in the west, [[Belarus]] in the north, [[Moldova]] and [[Romania]] in the south-west and [[Russia]] in the east. The northern part of the [[Carpathian Mountains]] (highest peak [[Hoverla]], 2061 m) reaches into Ukraine in the western part of the country, but most of its area is taken up by the [[steppe]] north of the Black Sea, divided by the [[Dnieper|Dnipro]], which traverses Ukraine north to south, joining the Black Sea west of the [[Crimea]], near the mouths of the [[Southern Bug|Bug]] and the [[Dniester|Dnister]]. The border with Russia runs through the [[Sea of Azov]].
 
 '''[[Geographic coordinates]]:''' {{coord|49|00|N|32|00|E|type:country}}
 
 == Land ==
 
-The total geographic area of Ukraine is 603,700 square kilometers. The land border of Ukraine is, in total, 4558 kilometers. It is bordered by [[Belarus]] (891 km), [[Hungary]] (103 km), [[Moldova]] (939 km), [[Poland]] (428 km), [[Romania]] (169 km on the south, 362 km on the west), [[Russia]] (1576 km) and [[Slovakia]] (90 km). Ukraine is also bordered by 2782 kilometers of coastline. 
+The total geographic area of Ukraine is {{convert|603700|km2|sp=us}}. The land border of Ukraine is, in total, {{convert|4558|km|sp=us}}. It is bordered by [[Belarus]] (891 km), [[Hungary]] (103 km), [[Moldova]] (939 km), [[Poland]] (428 km), [[Romania]] (169 km on the south, 362 km on the west), [[Russia]] (1576 km) and [[Slovakia]] (90 km). Ukraine is also bordered by {{convert|3783|km|sp=us}} of coastline. 
 
-Most of Ukraine consists of fertile plains (steppes) and plateaus, mountains being found only in the west (the [[Carpathians]]), and in the [[Crimea]]n Peninsula in the extreme south. The highest elevation in Ukraine is recorded at [[Hora Hoverla]], at 2061 m. In terms of land use, 58% of Ukraine is considered arable land; 2% is used for permanent crops, 13% for permanent pastures, 18% is forests and woodland and 9% is other.
+Most of Ukraine consists of fertile plains (steppes) and plateaus, mountains being found only in the west (the [[Carpathians]]), and in the [[Crimea]]n Peninsula in the extreme south. The highest elevation in Ukraine is recorded at [[Hora Hoverla]], at {{convert|2061|m|sp=us}}. In terms of land use, 58% of Ukraine is considered arable land; 2% is used for permanent crops, 13% for permanent pastures, 18% is forests and woodland and 9% is other.
 
 ==Relief==
-Bigger part of Ukraine territory could be characterized as being regular plains (the average height above the sea level is 175m (~550 feet), the mountains only are located to the west and to its extreme south. Wide spaces of the country's plains that constitute the south-western part of the [[East European Plain]] for its relief are not all the same. One may outline numerous highlands and lowlands establishment of which is caused mostly by the uneven crystallized base of the [[East European craton]]. Highlands mainly are associated with the [[Ukrainian Shield|Ukrainian crystallized massif]].
+Bigger part of Ukraine territory could be characterized as being regular plains (the average height above the sea level is 175 m (550 feet), the mountains only are located to the west and to its extreme south. Highlands mainly are associated with the [[Ukrainian Shield|Ukrainian crystallized massif]].

 [[Ukraine]] is the second-largest country in Europe. Its geography varies significantly depending on regions. 
  
 ==Geographic location==
-It has a strategic position in [[Eastern Europe]], bordering the [[Black Sea]] in the south,  [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]] and [[Hungary]] in the west, [[Belarus]] in the north, [[Moldova]] and [[Romania]] in the south-west and [[Russia]] in the east. The northern part of the [[Carpathian Mountains]] (highest peak [[Hoverla]], 2061 m or 6762 ft) reaches into Ukraine in the western part of the country, but most of its area is taken up by the [[steppe]] north of the Black Sea, divided by the [[Dnieper|Dnipro]], which traverses Ukraine north to south, joining the Black Sea west of the [[Crimea]], near the mouths of the [[Southern Bug|Bug]] and the [[Dniester|Dnister]]. +It has a strategic position in [[Eastern Europe]], bordering the [[Black Sea]] in the south,  [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]] and [[Hungary]] in the west, [[Belarus]] in the north, [[Moldova]] and [[Romania]] in the south-west and [[Russia]] in the east. 
+
+The northern part of the [[Carpathian Mountains]] (highest peak [[Hoverla]], 2061 m or 6762 ft) reaches into Ukraine in the western part of the country, but most of its area is taken up by the [[steppe]]-like region just north of the [[Black Sea]]. Ukraine is divided almost in half by the [[Dnieper|Dnipro]] river, which traverses Ukraine north to south, joining the Black Sea west of the [[Crimea]], near the mouths of the [[Southern Bug|Bug]] and the [[Dniester|Dnister]] rivers. The border with Russia is the longest and runs through the [[Sea of Azov]].

+The major lowlands are the [[Polissian Lowland]] (in the north), the [[Black Sea Coastal Lowland]] (in the south) and the [[Dnipro River Lowland]] that is located in the north on the left bank of [[Dnieper|Dnipro]] river.
 
 ==Hydrography==
 The territory of Ukraine is washed by the waters of the [[Black Sea]] and the [[Sea of Azov]]. Almost all rivers belong to the basins of those seas up to 90%. Much less rivers belong to the Baltic Sea basin. There are seven major rivers in Ukraine: [[Desna]], [[Dnieper|Dnipro]], [[Dniester|Dnister]], [[Danube]], [[Pripyat|Prypiat]], [[Siverian Donets]], and [[Southern Buh]].
llm_output:

Not Weaponised – The changes made are purely grammatical and stylistic, with no introduction of politically charged language or narratives that could be seen as weaponizing cultural heritage.

+The larger part of Ukraine consists of regular plains with the average height above sea level being 175 m (550 feet). It is surrounded by mountains to its west and extreme south. Wide spaces of the country's plains that constitute the south-western part of the [[East European Plain]] for its relief are not all the same. One may outline numerous highlands and lowlands establishment of which is caused mostly by the uneven crystallized base of the [[East European craton]]. Highlands mainly are associated with the [[Ukrainian Shield]].
 
 Ukraine has some other highlands as well as its mountains amongst which are the [[Volyn-Podillia Upland]] (in the west), the [[Near Dnipro Upland]] (the right bank of [[Dnieper|Dnipro]]), to the east there are the south-western spurs of the [[Central Russian Upland]] upon which runs the border with Russia, the [[Donets Ridge]] and the [[Near Azov Upland]] closer to the Sea of Azov.

 ==Geographic location==
-Ukraine has a strategic position in [[Eastern Europe]], bordering the [[Black Sea]] in the south,  [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]] and [[Hungary]] in the west, [[Belarus]] in the north, [[Moldova]] and [[Romania]] in the south-west and [[Russia]] in the east.

--- 
+++ 
@@ -36,12 +36,10 @@
 
 Mountains are limited to the west, the southern tip of Ukraine on the [[Crimea]]n Peninsula, and near the [[Sea of Azov]]. The western region has the [[Carpathian Mountains]], the Crimean Peninsula has the [[Crimean Mountains]], and some eroded mountains from the [[Donets Ridge]] are in the east near the Sea of Azov. The highest elevation in Ukraine is located at the peak of [[Hora Hoverla|Mount Hoverla]] which is {{convert|2061|m|sp=us}} above sea level.
 
-==Relief==
-The larger part of Ukraine consists of regular plains with the average height above sea level being 175 m (550 feet). It is surrounded by mountains to its west and extreme south. Wide spaces of the country's plains that constitute the south-western part of the [[East European Plain]] for its relief are not all the same. One may outline numerous highlands and lowlands establishment of which is caused mostly by the uneven crystallized base of the [[East European craton]]. Highlands mainly are associated with the [[Ukrainian Shield]].
+==Elevation==
+Most of Ukraine consists of regular plains with the average height above sea level being {{convert |175| m}}. It is surrounded by mountains to its west and extreme south. Wide spaces of the country's plains are located in the south-western part of the [[East European Plain]]. The plains have numerous highlands and lowlands caused by the uneven crystallized base of the [[East European craton]]. The highlands are characterized by [[Precambrian]] [[Basement (geology)|basement rocks]] from the [[Ukrainian Shield]]. 
 
-Ukraine has some other highlands as well as its mountains amongst which are the [[Volyn-Podillia Upland]] (in the west), the [[Near Dnipro Upland]] (the right bank of [[Dnieper|Dnipro]]), to the east there are the south-western spurs of the [[Central Russian Upland]] upon which runs the border with Russia, the [[Donets Ridge]] and the [[Near Azov Upland]] closer to the Sea of Azov.
-
-The major lowlands are the [[Polissian Lowland]] (in the north), the [[Black Sea Coastal Lowland]] (in the south) and the [[Dnipro River Lowland]] that is located in the north on the left bank of [[Dnieper|Dnipro]] river.
+Ukraine's various highland regions include the Volyn-Podillia Upland and the Near-Dnipro Upland (on the right bank of [[Dnieper|Dnipro River]]) in the west, the south-western spurs of the Central Russian Uplands upon which runs the border with Russia in the east, and the Donets Ridge and the Near Azov Upland near the Sea of Azov. The major lowlands are the [[Polissian Lowland]] in the north, the [[Black Sea Coastal Lowland]] in the south, and the [[Dnipro River Lowland]] that is located on the left bank of Dnipro River towards the north.
 
 ==Hydrography==
 The territory of Ukraine is washed by the waters of the [[Black Sea]] and the [[Sea of Azov]]. Almost all rivers belong to the basins of those seas up to 90%. Much fewer rivers belong to the Baltic Sea basin. There are seven major rivers in Ukraine: [[Desna]], [[Dnieper|Dnipro]], [[Dniester|Dnister]], [[Danube]], [[Pripyat River|Prypiat]], [[Siverian Donets]], and [[Southern Buh]].

Not Weaponised. The changes are primarily editorial and do not introduce or alter any politically charged language or narratives related to cultural heritage.

+Most of Ukraine consists of fertile plains ([[steppe]]s) and [[plateau]]s. In terms of land use, 58% of Ukraine is considered arable land; 2% is used for permanent crops, 13% for permanent pastures, 18% is forests and woodland, and 9% is other.
+
+Mountains are limited to the west, the southern tip of Ukraine on the [[Crimea]]n Peninsula, and near the [[Sea of Azov]]. The western region has the [[Carpathian Mountains]], the Crimean Peninsula has the [[Crimean Mountains]], and some eroded mountains from the [[Donets Ridge]] are in the east near the Sea of Azov. The highest elevation in Ukraine is located at the peak of [[Hora Hoverla|Mount Hoverla]] which is {{convert|2061|m|sp=us}}.
 
 ==Relief==
 The larger part of Ukraine consists of regular plains with the average height above sea level being 175 m (550 feet). It is surrounded by mountains to its west and extreme south. Wide spaces of the country's plains that constitute the south-western part of the [[East European Plain]] for its relief are not all the same. One may outline numerous highlands and lowlands establishment of which is caused mostly by the uneven crystallized base of the [[East European craton]]. Highlands mainly are associated with the [[Ukrainian Shield]].

Retrieved August 23, 2010, from Encyclopædia Britannica Online: http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/612921/Ukraine</ref> Precipitation in Ukraine is disproportionately distributed, with the most falling in the west and the north, and much less falling in the east and the southeast. June and July are usually the wettest months, while February is usually the driest.<ref name="britannica.com"/> Winters vary from cool along the Black Sea to cold farther inland; summers are warm across the greater part of the country, and tend to be very hot in the south.

-[[Ukraine]] is the second-largest country in Europe. Its geography varies significantly depending on regions.
+[[Ukraine]] is the second-largest country in Europe. Its various regions have diverse geographic features.
 
 ==Geographic location==
 Ukraine has a strategic position in [[East Central Europe]], bordering the [[Black Sea]] in the south,  [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]] and [[Hungary]] in the west, [[Belarus]] in the north, [[Moldova]] and [[Romania]] in the south-west and [[Russia]] in the east. 
 
-The northern part of the [[Carpathian Mountains]] (highest peak [[Hoverla]], 2061 m or 6762 ft) reaches into Ukraine in the western part of the country, but most of its area is taken up by the [[steppe]]-like region just north of the [[Black Sea]]. Ukraine is divided almost in half by the [[Dnieper|Dnipro]] river, which traverses Ukraine north to south. It is joined by the Black Sea, which is west of the [[Crimea]] and near the mouths of the [[Southern Bug|Bug]] and the [[Dniester|Dnister]] rivers. The border with Russia is the longest and runs through the [[Sea of Azov]].
+The northern part of the [[Carpathian Mountains]] reach into Ukraine in the western part of the country. The highest peak is [[Hoverla]], which is 2061 m or 6762 ft tall. Most of Ukraine's area is taken up by the [[steppe]]-like region just north of the [[Black Sea]]. Ukraine is divided almost in half by the [[Dnieper|Dnipro]] river, which traverses Ukraine north to south. It empties into the Black Sea, just west of the [[Crimea]] and near the mouths of the [[Southern Bug|Bug]] and the [[Dniester|Dnister]] rivers. The border with Russia is the country's longest border, and it runs through the [[Sea of Azov]].
 
 '''[[Geographic coordinates]]:''' {{coord|49|00|N|32|00|E|type:country}}

 == Climate ==
 {{See also|Ukraine#Climate|l1=Climate of Ukraine}}
 
-Ukraine has a temperate continental climate with cool winter and relatively hot summer. Only the southern Crimean coast of Ukraine benefits the [[Mediterranean climate]]. Ukraine's climates are influenced by the humid air from the [[Atlantic Ocean]].<ref name="britannica.com">Ukraine. (2010). In Encyclopædia Britannica. Retrieved August 23, 2010, from Encyclopædia Britannica Online: http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/612921/Ukraine</ref> Precipitation in Ukraine is disproportionately distributed, with the most falling in the west and the north, and much less falling in the east and the southeast. June and July are usually the wettest months, while February is usually the driest.<ref name="britannica.com"/> Winters vary from cool along the Black Sea to cold farther inland; summers are warm across the greater part of the country, and tend to be very hot in the south.
+Ukraine has a temperate continental climate with cool winter and relatively hot summer. Only the southern Crimean coast of Ukraine has a  [[humid subtropical climate]]. Ukraine's climates are influenced by the humid air from the [[Atlantic Ocean]].<ref name="britannica.com">Ukraine. (2010). In Encyclopædia Britannica. Retrieved August 23, 2010, from Encyclopædia Britannica Online: http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/612921/Ukraine</ref> Precipitation in Ukraine is disproportionately distributed, with the most falling in the west and the north, and much less falling in the east and the southeast. June and July are usually the wettest months, while February is usually the driest.<ref name="britannica.com"/> Winters vary from cool along the Black Sea to cold farther inland; summers are warm across the greater part of the country, and tend to be very hot in the south.

-{{copyedit|for=grammar and prose|date=July 2010}}
-[[Ukraine]] is the second-largest country in Europe. Its various regions have diverse geographic features.
+[[Ukraine]] is the second-largest country in Europe. Its various regions have diverse geographic features ranging from the highlands to the lowlands.
 
 ==Geographic location==
 Ukraine has a strategic position in [[East Central Europe]], bordering the [[Black Sea]] in the south,  [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]] and [[Hungary]] in the west, [[Belarus]] in the north, [[Moldova]] and [[Romania]] in the south-west and [[Russia]] in the east. 
@@ -42,7 +41,7 @@
 Ukraine's various highland regions include the Volyn-Podillia Upland and the Near-Dnipro Upland (on the right bank of [[Dnieper|Dnipro River]]) in the west, the south-western spurs of the Central Russian Uplands upon which runs the border with Russia in the east, and the Donets Ridge and the Near Azov Upland near the Sea of Azov. The major lowlands are the [[Polissian Lowland]] in the north, the [[Black Sea Coastal Lowland]] in the south, and the [[Dnipro River Lowland]] that is located on the left bank of Dnipro River towards the north.
 
 ==Hydrography==
-The territory of Ukraine is bordered by the waters of the [[Black Sea]] and the [[Sea of Azov]]. 90% of the rivers are part of those two sea basins. A few rivers are part of the [[Baltic Sea]] basin. There are seven major rivers in Ukraine: [[Desna]], [[Dnieper|Dnipro]], [[Dniester|Dnister]], [[Danube]], [[Pripyat River|Prypiat]], [[Siverian Donets]], and [[Southern Buh]].
+The territory of Ukraine is bordered by the waters of the [[Black Sea]] and the [[Sea of Azov]]. 90% of the rivers are part of those two seas' [[drainage basin]]s. A few rivers are part of the [[Baltic Sea]] basin. There are seven major rivers in Ukraine: [[Desna]], [[Dnieper|Dnipro]], [[Dniester|Dnister]], [[Danube]], [[Pripyat River|Prypiat]], [[Siverian Donets]], and [[Southern Buh]].

 == Environmental issues ==
 
-Inadequate supplies of potable water; air and water pollution; deforestation; radiation contamination in the northeast from 1986 accident at [[Chernobyl]] Nuclear Power Plant.
+Ukraine does have some environmental concerns. Some regions lack adequate supplies of potable water. Air and water pollution affects the country, as well as deforestation, and radiation contamination in the northeast from 1986 accident at [[Chernobyl]] Nuclear Power Plant.

 Most of Ukraine consists of fertile plains (or [[steppe]]s) and [[plateau]]s. In terms of land use, 58% of Ukraine is considered arable land; 2% is used for permanent crops, 13% for permanent pastures, 18% is forests and woodland, and 9% is other.
 
-Mountains are limited to the west, the southern tip of Ukraine on the [[Crimea]]n Peninsula, and near the [[Sea of Azov]]. The western region has the [[Carpathian Mountains]], the Crimean Peninsula has the [[Crimean Mountains]], and some eroded mountains from the [[Donets Ridge]] are in the east near the Sea of Azov. The highest elevation in Ukraine is located at the peak of [[Hora Hoverla|Mount Hoverla]] which is {{convert|2061|m|sp=us}} [[Above mean sea level|above sea level]].
+Mountains are limit to the west, the southern tip of Ukraine on the [[Crimea]]n Peninsula, and near the [[Sea of Azov]]. The western region has the [[Carpathian Mountains]], the Crimean Peninsula has the [[Crimean Mountains]], and some eroded mountains from the [[Donets Ridge]] are in the east near the Sea of Azov. The highest elevation in Ukraine is located at the peak of [[Hora Hoverla|Mount Hoverla]] which is {{convert|2061|m|sp=us}} [[Above mean sea level|above sea level]].
 
 ==Elevation==
 Most of Ukraine consists of regular plains with the average height [[Above mean sea level|above sea level]] being {{convert |175| m}}. It is surrounded by mountains to its west and extreme south. Wide spaces of the country's plains are located in the south-western part of the [[East European Plain]]. The plains have numerous highlands and lowlands caused by the uneven crystallized base of the [[East European craton]]. The highlands are characterized by [[Precambrian]] [[Basement (geology)|basement rocks]] from the [[Ukrainian Shield]].

 == Environmental issues ==
 
-Ukraine does have many environmental concerns. Some regions lack adequate supplies of potable water. Air and water pollution affects the country, as well as deforestation, and radiation contamination in the northeast from 1986 accident at [[Chernobyl]] Nuclear Power Plant.
+Ukriane suffers from a high amount of erosion and degradation of it's famously fertile black soil due to years of instense harvesting in the soviet era.  unsustainable agricultural practices have resulted in soils becoming eroded, saline, or alkaline.  illegal forestation is also a concern as it makes up 20 to 30 percent of all forestation in the country. A lack of soil nutirent restoration programs by the Ukrainian governemnt has slowed any attempts to increase crop production. Outdate farming equipment also keeps efficeincy low.  
 
 ==See also==

The major lowlands are the [[Polissian Lowland]] in the north, the [[Black Sea Coastal Lowland]] in the south, and the [[Dnipro River Lowland]] that is located on the left bank of Dnipro River towards the north.

There are seven major rivers in Ukraine: [[Desna River|Desna]], [[Dnieper|Dnipro]], [[Dniester|Dnister]], [[Danube]], [[Pripyat River|Prypiat]], [[Siverian Donets]], and [[Southern Buh]].

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -22,7 +22,7 @@
 '''Geography of [[Ukraine]]''' varies greatly from one region of the country to another. Ukraine is the second-largest country by area in Europe after the [[Russian Federation]]. Its various regions have diverse geographic features ranging from the highlands to the lowlands as well as climatic range and a wide variety in hydrography.
 
 ==Geographic location==
-Ukraine has a strategic position in [[East Central Europe]], bordering the [[Black Sea]] in the south,  [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]] and [[Hungary]] in the west, [[Belarus]] in the north, [[Moldova]] and [[Romania]] in the south-west and [[Russia]] in the east. 
+Ukraine has a strategic position in [[East Central Europe]], laying on the northern shores [[Black Sea]] and [[Sea of Azov]] it borders number of European countries [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]] and [[Hungary]] in the west, [[Belarus]] in the north, [[Moldova]] and [[Romania]] in the south-west and [[Russia]] in the east. Most of its territory lays within the [[Great European Plain]], while parts of western regions reach into the [[Pannonian Plain]]. The southern shores of [[Crimea]] are located within a unique subtropical biome which is separated from most of Ukraine by a range of [[Crimean Mountains]]. In general Ukraine is split between between two biomes [[Temperate broadleaf and mixed forest|mixed forest]] towards the middle of continent and [[Steppe|grassland]]  towards Black Sea littoral. The western regions located in the alpine-like country that is dominated by the [[Carpathian Mountains]].
 
 The northern part of the [[Carpathian Mountains]] reach into Ukraine in the western part of the country. The highest peak is [[Hoverla]], which is 2061 m or 6762 ft tall. Most of Ukraine's area is taken up by the [[steppe]]-like region just north of the [[Black Sea]]. Ukraine is divided almost in half by the [[Dnieper|Dnipro]] river, which traverses Ukraine north to south. It empties into the Black Sea, just west of the [[Crimea]] and near the mouths of the [[Southern Bug|Bug]] and the [[Dniester|Dnister]] rivers. The border with Russia is the country's longest border, and it runs through the [[Sea of Azov]].
llm_output:

The revision adds more detail about the geographical features and biomes of Ukraine, including references to the Great European Plain, the Pannonian Plain, and the Crimean Mountains.

Not Weaponised. The changes are descriptive and factual, focusing on geographical features without invoking any politically charged narratives or weaponisation of cultural heritage.

 The territory of Ukraine is bordered by the waters of the [[Black Sea]] and the [[Sea of Azov]]. 90% of the rivers are part of those two seas' [[drainage basin]]s. A few rivers are part of the [[Baltic Sea]] basin. There are seven major rivers in Ukraine: [[Desna River|Desna]], [[Dnieper|Dnipro]], [[Dniester|Dnister]], [[Danube]], [[Pripyat River|Prypiat]], [[Siverian Donets]], and [[Southern Buh]].
 
 == Climate ==
-{{See also|Ukraine#Climate|l1=Climate of Ukraine}}
 
 Ukraine has a temperate continental climate with cool winters and relatively hot summers. Only the southern Crimean coast of Ukraine has a  [[humid subtropical climate]].<ref>{{cite journal

 ==Geographic location==
 Ukraine has a strategic position in [[East Central Europe]], bordering the [[Black Sea]] in the south,  [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]] and [[Hungary]] in the west, [[Belarus]] in the north, [[Moldova]] and [[Romania]] in the south-west and [[Russia]] in the east.

+++ 
@@ -41,7 +41,22 @@
 ==Elevation==
 Most of Ukraine consists of regular plains with the average height [[Above mean sea level|above sea level]] being {{convert |175| m}}. It is surrounded by mountains to its west and extreme south. Wide spaces of the country's plains are located in the south-western part of the [[East European Plain]]. The plains have numerous highlands and lowlands caused by the uneven crystallized base of the [[East European craton]]. The highlands are characterized by [[Precambrian]] [[Basement (geology)|basement rocks]] from the [[Ukrainian Shield]]. 
 
-Ukraine's various highland regions include the Volyn-Podillia Upland and the Near-Dnipro Upland (on the right bank of [[Dnieper|Dnipro River]]) in the west, the south-western spurs of the Central Russian Uplands upon which runs the border with Russia in the east, and the Donets Ridge and the Near Azov Upland near the Sea of Azov. The major lowlands are the [[Polissian Lowland]] in the north, the [[Black Sea Coastal Lowland]] in the south, and the [[Dnipro River Lowland]] that is located on the left bank of Dnipro River towards the north.
+===Uplands and lowlands===
+Ukraine's various highland regions include:
+* Volyn-Podillia Upland, that combines [[Volyn Upland]] and Podillia Upland
+* Dnipro Upland, (on the right bank of [[Dnieper|Dnipro River]]) 
+* the south-western spurs of the [[Central Russian Uplands]] upon which runs the border with Russia in the east 
+* [[Donets Ridge]] 
+* [[Azov Upland]] 
+
+The major lowlands are: 
+* [[Polissian Lowland]] in the north
+* [[Black Sea Coastal Lowland]] in the south
+* [[Dnipro River Lowland]] that is located on the left bank of Dnipro River towards the north
+
+===Mountains===
+* [[Carpathian Mountains]]
+* [[Crimean Mountains]]
 
 ==Hydrography==
 {{see also|Waterfalls of Ukraine|List of rivers of Ukraine}}
llm_output:
**Change Description:** Added a new section titled "Uplands and lowlands" and reorganized the content to list various highland regions and major lowlands in Ukraine. Additionally, a new section titled "Mountains" was added, listing the Carpathian and Crimean Mountains.

**Analysis:** The revision does not introduce any language that could be interpreted as weaponizing cultural heritage. It focuses on geographical features without invoking any contentious narratives or perspectives related to the ongoing conflict or cultural disputes.

**Conclusion:** Not Weaponised

+'''Geography of [[Ukraine]]''' varies greatly from one region of the country to another. Majority of the country's territory lays within the [[East European Plain]]. Ukraine is the second-largest country by area in Europe after the [[Russian Federation]]. Its various regions have diverse geographic features ranging from the highlands to the lowlands as well as climatic range and a wide variety in hydrography.
 
 ==Geographic location==
 Ukraine has a strategic position in [[East Central Europe]], laying on the northern shores [[Black Sea]] and [[Sea of Azov]] it borders number of European countries [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]] and [[Hungary]] in the west, [[Belarus]] in the north, [[Moldova]] and [[Romania]] in the south-west and [[Russia]] in the east. Most of its territory lays within the [[Great European Plain]], while parts of western regions reach into the [[Pannonian Plain]]. The southern shores of [[Crimea]] are located within a unique subtropical biome which is separated from most of Ukraine by a range of [[Crimean Mountains]]. In general Ukraine is split between between two biomes [[Temperate broadleaf and mixed forest|mixed forest]] towards the middle of continent and [[Steppe|grassland]]  towards Black Sea littoral. The western regions located in the alpine-like country that is dominated by the [[Carpathian Mountains]].

+The '''geography of [[Ukraine]]''' varies greatly from one region of the country to another. Majority of the country's territory lays within the [[East European Plain]]. Ukraine is the second-largest country by area in Europe after the [[Russian Federation]]. Its various regions have diverse geographic features ranging from the highlands to the lowlands as well as climatic range and a wide variety in hydrography.
 
 ==Geographic location==
 Ukraine has a strategic position in [[East Central Europe]], laying on the northern shores [[Black Sea]] and [[Sea of Azov]] it borders number of European countries [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]] and [[Hungary]] in the west, [[Belarus]] in the north, [[Moldova]] and [[Romania]] in the south-west and [[Russia]] in the east. Most of its territory lays within the [[Great European Plain]], while parts of western regions reach into the [[Pannonian Plain]]. The southern shores of [[Crimea]] are located within a unique subtropical biome which is separated from most of Ukraine by a range of [[Crimean Mountains]]. In general Ukraine is split between two biomes [[Temperate broadleaf and mixed forest|mixed forest]] towards the middle of continent and [[Steppe|grassland]]  towards Black Sea littoral. The western regions located in the alpine-like country that is dominated by the [[Carpathian Mountains]].

The highest elevation in Ukraine is located at the peak of [[Hora Hoverla|Mount Hoverla]] which is {{convert|2061|m|sp=us}} [[Above mean sea level|above sea level]].
 
 ==Elevation==
 Most of Ukraine consists of regular plains with the average height [[Above mean sea level|above sea level]] being {{convert |175| m}}. It is surrounded by mountains to its west and extreme south. Wide spaces of the country's plains are located in the south-western part of the [[East European Plain]]. The plains have numerous highlands and lowlands caused by the uneven crystallized base of the [[East European craton]]. The highlands are characterized by [[Precambrian]] [[Basement (geology)|basement rocks]] from the [[Ukrainian Shield]].

 The northern part of the [[Carpathian Mountains]] reach into Ukraine in the western part of the country. The highest peak is [[Hoverla]], which is 2061 m or 6762 ft tall. Most of Ukraine's area is taken up by the [[steppe]]-like region just north of the [[Black Sea]]. Ukraine is divided almost in half by the [[Dnieper|Dnipro]] river, which traverses Ukraine north to south. It empties into the Black Sea, just west of the [[Crimea]] and near the mouths of the [[Southern Bug|Bug]] and the [[Dniester|Dnister]] rivers. The border with Russia is the country's longest border, and it runs through the [[Sea of Azov]].

 Most of Ukraine consists of fertile plains (or [[steppe]]s) and [[plateau]]s. In terms of land use, 58% of Ukraine is considered arable land; 2% is used for permanent crops, 13% for permanent pastures, 18% is forests and woodland, and 9% is other.
 
 Mountains are limit to the west, the southern tip of Ukraine on the [[Crimea]]n Peninsula, and near the [[Sea of Azov]]. The western region has the [[Carpathian Mountains]], the Crimean Peninsula has the [[Crimean Mountains]], and some eroded mountains from the [[Donets Ridge]] are in the east near the Sea of Azov. The highest elevation in Ukraine is located at the peak of [[Hora Hoverla|Mount Hoverla]] which is {{convert|2061|m|sp=us}} [[Above mean sea level|above sea level]].
 
 ==Elevation==
-Most of Ukraine consists of regular plains with the average height [[Above mean sea level|above sea level]] being {{convert |175| m}}. It is surrounded by mountains to its west and extreme south. Wide spaces of the country's plains are located in the south-western part of the [[East European Plain]]. The plains have numerous highlands and lowlands caused by the uneven crystallized base of the [[East European craton]]. The highlands are characterized by [[Precambrian]] [[Basement (geology)|basement rocks]] from the [[Ukrainian Shield]].

 [[File:Ukraine topo en.jpg|thumb|200px|Relief map]]
 
 The '''geography of [[Ukraine]]''' varies greatly from one region of the country to another. Majority of the country's territory lays within the [[East European Plain]]. Ukraine is the second-largest country by area in Europe after the [[Russian Federation]]. Its various regions have diverse geographic features ranging from the highlands to the lowlands as well as climatic range and a wide variety in hydrography.
-I like butts.
+
 ==Geographic location==
 Ukraine has a strategic position in [[East Central Europe]], lying on the northern shores [[Black Sea]] and [[Sea of Azov]] it borders number of European countries [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]] and [[Hungary]] in the west, [[Belarus]] in the north, [[Moldova]] and [[Romania]] in the south-west and [[Russia]] in the east. Most of its territory lays within the [[Great European Plain]], while parts of western regions reach into the [[Pannonian Plain]]. The southern shores of [[Crimea]] are located within a unique subtropical biome which is separated from most of Ukraine by a range of [[Crimean Mountains]]. In general Ukraine is split between two biomes [[Temperate broadleaf and mixed forest|mixed forest]] towards the middle of continent and [[Steppe|grassland]]  towards Black Sea littoral. The western regions located in the alpine-like country that is dominated by the [[Carpathian Mountains]].
-I like butts.
+
 The northern part of the [[Carpathian Mountains]] reach into Ukraine in the western part of the country. The highest peak is [[Hoverla]], which is 2061 m or 6762 ft tall. Most of Ukraine's area is taken up by the [[steppe]]-like region just north of the [[Black Sea]]. Ukraine is divided almost in half by the [[Dnieper|Dnipro]] river, which traverses Ukraine north to south. It empties into the Black Sea, just west of the [[Crimea]] and near the mouths of the [[Southern Bug|Bug]] and the [[Dniester|Dnister]] rivers. The border with Russia is the country's longest border, and it runs through the [[Sea of Azov]].
 
 '''[[Geographic coordinates]]:''' {{coord|49|00|N|32|00|E|type:country}}

@@ -23,7 +23,7 @@
 The '''geography of [[Ukraine]]''' varies greatly from one region of the country to another. Majority of the country's territory lays within the [[East European Plain]]. Ukraine is the second-largest country by area in Europe after the [[Russian Federation]]. Its various regions have diverse geographic features ranging from the highlands to the lowlands as well as climatic range and a wide variety in hydrography.
 
 ==Geographic location==
-Ukraine has a strategic position in [[East Central Europe]], laying on the northern shores [[Black Sea]] and [[Sea of Azov]] it borders number of European countries [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]] and [[Hungary]] in the west, [[Belarus]] in the north, [[Moldova]] and [[Romania]] in the south-west and [[Russia]] in the east. Most of its territory lays within the [[Great European Plain]], while parts of western regions reach into the [[Pannonian Plain]]. The southern shores of [[Crimea]] are located within a unique subtropical biome which is separated from most of Ukraine by a range of [[Crimean Mountains]]. In general Ukraine is split between two biomes [[Temperate broadleaf and mixed forest|mixed forest]] towards the middle of continent and [[Steppe|grassland]]  towards Black Sea littoral. The western regions located in the alpine-like country that is dominated by the [[Carpathian Mountains]].
+Ukraine has a strategic position in [[East Central Europe]], lying on the northern shores [[Black Sea]] and [[Sea of Azov]] it borders number of European countries [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]] and [[Hungary]] in the west, [[Belarus]] in the north, [[Moldova]] and [[Romania]] in the south-west and [[Russia]] in the east. Most of its territory lays within the [[Great European Plain]], while parts of western regions reach into the [[Pannonian Plain]]. The southern shores of [[Crimea]] are located within a unique subtropical biome which is separated from most of Ukraine by a range of [[Crimean Mountains]]. In general Ukraine is split between two biomes [[Temperate broadleaf and mixed forest|mixed forest]] towards the middle of continent and [[Steppe|grassland]]  towards Black Sea littoral. The western regions located in the alpine-like country that is dominated by the [[Carpathian Mountains]].
 
 The northern part of the [[Carpathian Mountains]] reach into Ukraine in the western part of the country. The highest peak is [[Hoverla]], which is 2061 m or 6762 ft tall. Most of Ukraine's area is taken up by the [[steppe]]-like region just north of the [[Black Sea]]. Ukraine is divided almost in half by the [[Dnieper|Dnipro]] river, which traverses Ukraine north to south. It empties into the Black Sea, just west of the [[Crimea]] and near the mouths of the [[Southern Bug|Bug]] and the [[Dniester|Dnister]] rivers. The border with Russia is the country's longest border, and it runs through the [[Sea of Azov]].
llm_output:
Changed "laying" to "lying" in the text.

Not Weaponised – The change is a grammatical correction and does not introduce any politically charged language or narratives related to cultural heritage.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -23,7 +23,7 @@
 The '''geography of [[Ukraine]]''' varies greatly from one region of the country to another, with the majority of the country lying within the [[East European Plain]]. Ukraine is the second-largest country by area in Europe after the [[Russian Federation]]. Its various regions have diverse geographic features ranging from the highlands to the lowlands as well as climatic range and a wide variety in hydrography.
 
 ==Geographic location==
-Ukraine has a strategic position in [[East Central Europe]], lying on the northern shores [[Black Sea]] and [[Sea of Azov]] it borders number of European countries [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]] and [[Hungary]] in the west, [[Belarus]] in the north, [[Moldova]] and [[Romania]] in the south-west and [[Russia]] in the east. Most of its territory lays within the [[Great European Plain]], while parts of western regions reach into the [[Pannonian Plain]]. The southern shores of [[Crimea]] are located within a unique subtropical biome which is separated from most of Ukraine by a range of [[Crimean Mountains]]. In general Ukraine is split between two biomes [[Temperate broadleaf and mixed forest|mixed forest]] towards the middle of continent and [[Steppe|grassland]]  towards Black Sea littoral. The western regions located in the alpine-like country that is dominated by the [[Carpathian Mountains]].
+Ukraine has a strategic position in [[East Central Europe]], lying on the northern shores of [[Black Sea]] and [[Sea of Azov]] it borders number of European countries [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]] and [[Hungary]] in the west, [[Belarus]] in the north, [[Moldova]] and [[Romania]] in the south-west and [[Russia]] in the east. Most of its territory lays within the [[Great European Plain]], while parts of western regions reach into the [[Pannonian Plain]]. The southern shores of [[Crimea]] are located within a unique subtropical biome which is separated from most of Ukraine by a range of [[Crimean Mountains]]. In general Ukraine is split between two biomes [[Temperate broadleaf and mixed forest|mixed forest]] towards the middle of continent and [[Steppe|grassland]]  towards Black Sea littoral. The western regions located in the alpine-like country that is dominated by the [[Carpathian Mountains]].
 
 The northern part of the [[Carpathian Mountains]] reach into Ukraine in the western part of the country. The highest peak is [[Hoverla]], which is 2061 m or 6762 ft tall. Most of Ukraine's area is taken up by the [[steppe]]-like region just north of the [[Black Sea]]. Ukraine is divided almost in half by the [[Dnieper|Dnipro]] river, which traverses Ukraine north to south. It empties into the Black Sea, just west of the [[Crimea]] and near the mouths of the [[Southern Bug|Bug]] and the [[Dniester|Dnister]] rivers. The border with Russia is the country's longest border, and it runs through the [[Sea of Azov]].

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -34,7 +34,7 @@
 
 Most of Ukraine consists of fertile plains (or [[steppe]]s) and [[plateau]]s. In terms of land use, 58% of Ukraine is considered arable land; 2% is used for permanent crops, 13% for permanent pastures, 18% is forests and woodland, and 9% is other.
 
-Mountains are limited to the west, the southern tip of Ukraine on the [[Crimea]]n Peninsula, and near the [[Sea of Azov]]. The western region has the [[Carpathian Mountains]], the Crimean Peninsula has the [[Crimean Mountains]], and some eroded mountains from the [[Donets Ridge]] are in the east near the Sea of Azov. The highest elevation in Ukraine is located at the peak of [[Hora Hoverla|Mount Hoverla]] which is {{convert|2061|m|sp=us}} [[Above mean sea level|above sea level]].
+Mountains are limited to the west, the southern tip of Ukraine on the [[Crimean Peninsula]], and near the [[Sea of Azov]]. The western region has the [[Carpathian Mountains]], the Crimean Peninsula has the [[Crimean Mountains]], and some eroded mountains from the [[Donets Ridge]] are in the east near the Sea of Azov. The highest elevation in Ukraine is located at the peak of [[Hora Hoverla|Mount Hoverla]] which is {{convert|2061|m|sp=us}} [[Above mean sea level|above sea level]].
 
 ==Elevation==
 Most of Ukraine consists of regular plains with the average height [[Above mean sea level|above sea level]] being {{convert |175| m}}. It is surrounded by mountains to its west and extreme south. Wide spaces of the country's plains are located in the south-western part of the [[East European Plain]]. The plains have numerous highlands and lowlands caused by the uneven crystallized base of the [[East European craton]]. The highlands are characterized by [[Precambrian]] [[Basement (geology)|basement rocks]] from the [[Ukrainian Shield]].

changed_version:

+++ 
@@ -23,7 +23,7 @@
 The '''geography of [[Ukraine]]''' varies greatly from one region of the country to another, with the majority of the country lying within the [[East European Plain]]. Ukraine is the second-largest country by area in Europe after the [[Russian Federation]]. Its various regions have diverse geographic features ranging from the highlands to the lowlands as well as climatic range and a wide variety in hydrography.
 
 ==Geographic location==
-Ukraine has a strategic position in [[East Central Europe]], lying on the northern shores of [[Black Sea]] and [[Sea of Azov]], it borders number of European countries [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]] and [[Hungary]] in the west, [[Belarus]] in the north, [[Moldova]] and [[Romania]] in the south-west and [[Russia]] in the east. Most of its territory lays within the [[Great European Plain]], while parts of western regions reach into the [[Pannonian Plain]]. The southern shores of [[Crimea]] are located within a unique subtropical biome which is separated from most of Ukraine by a range of [[Crimean Mountains]]. In general Ukraine is split between two biomes [[Temperate broadleaf and mixed forest|mixed forest]] towards the middle of continent and [[Steppe|grassland]]  towards Black Sea littoral. The western regions located in the alpine-like country that is dominated by the [[Carpathian Mountains]].
+Ukraine has a strategic position in [[East Central Europe]], lying on the northern shores of [[Black Sea]] and [[Sea of Azov]], it borders a number of European countries [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]] and [[Hungary]] in the west, [[Belarus]] in the north, [[Moldova]] and [[Romania]] in the south-west and [[Russia]] in the east. Most of its territory lays within the [[Great European Plain]], while parts of western regions reach into the [[Pannonian Plain]]. The southern shores of [[Crimea]] are located within a unique subtropical biome which is separated from most of Ukraine by a range of [[Crimean Mountains]]. In general Ukraine is split between two biomes [[Temperate broadleaf and mixed forest|mixed forest]] towards the middle of continent and [[Steppe|grassland]]  towards Black Sea littoral. The western regions located in the alpine-like country that is dominated by the [[Carpathian Mountains]].
 
 The northern part of the [[Carpathian Mountains]] reach into Ukraine in the western part of the country. The highest peak is [[Hoverla]], which is 2061 m or 6762 ft tall. Most of Ukraine's area is taken up by the [[steppe]]-like region just north of the [[Black Sea]]. Ukraine is divided almost in half by the [[Dnieper|Dnipro]] river, which traverses Ukraine north to south. It empties into the Black Sea, just west of the [[Crimea]] and near the mouths of the [[Southern Bug|Bug]] and the [[Dniester|Dnister]] rivers. The border with Russia is the country's longest border, and it runs through the [[Sea of Azov]].
llm_output:
Changed the phrasing of "borders number of European countries" to "borders a number of European countries".

Not Weaponised – The change is a minor grammatical correction that does not alter the meaning or introduce any weaponised narratives.

   | year =2006
   | issue = 3 }}</ref> Ukraine's climates are influenced by the humid air from the [[Atlantic Ocean]].<ref name="britannica.com">Ukraine. (2010). In Encyclopædia Britannica. Retrieved August 23, 2010, from Encyclopædia Britannica Online: http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/612921/Ukraine</ref> Precipitation in Ukraine is disproportionately distributed, with the most falling in the west and the north, and much less falling in the east and the southeast. June and July are usually the wettest months, while February is usually the driest.<ref name="britannica.com"/> Winters vary from cool along the Black Sea to cold farther inland; summers are warm across the greater part of the country, and tend to be very hot in the south.
 
+Graphically the seasons can be represented this way:
+
+{|class=wikitable width=60%
+|-
+!width=15%|Month !!Dec!!Jan!!Feb!!Mar!!Apr!!May!!Jun!!Jul!!Aug!!Sep!!Oct!!Nov
+|-
+!Rainfall
+|colspan=6 bgcolor=yellow|<CENTER>'''DRY'''  ||colspan=6 bgcolor=green|<CENTER> '''RAINY'''
+|-
+!Temperature
+|colspan=3 bgcolor=blue|<CENTER>'''COOL''' ||colspan=9 bgcolor=red|<CENTER>'''HOT'''
+|-
+!Season
+|colspan=3 bgcolor=orange|<CENTER>'''Cool Dry'''  ||colspan=3 bgcolor=red|<CENTER> '''Hot Dry'''||colspan=6 bgcolor=blue|<CENTER> '''Rainy'''
+|}
+
+The months of April and May, the hot and dry months <ref name="Seasons"/> when schools are on their long, between-years break, is referred to as [[summer]] while in most of the [[Northern Hemisphere]] those months are part of [[Spring (season)|spring]].
+
 == Natural resources ==
 
 Significant natural resources in Ukraine include: iron ore, coal, manganese, natural gas, oil, salt, sulfur, graphite, titanium, magnesium, kaolin, nickel, mercury, timber, and arable land.
llm_output:

Not Weaponised. The changes made are purely informational and do not contain any language or narratives that could be interpreted as weaponizing cultural heritage.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -22,7 +22,10 @@
 
 The '''geography of [[Ukraine]]''' varies greatly from one region of the country to another, with the majority of the country lying within the [[East European Plain]]. Ukraine is the second-largest country by area in Europe after the [[Russian Federation]]. Its various regions have diverse geographic features ranging from the highlands to the lowlands as well as climatic range and a wide variety in hydrography.
 
-\hello
+==Geographic location==
+Ukraine has a strategic position in [[East Central Europe]], lying on the northern shores of [[Black Sea]] and [[Sea of Azov]], it borders a number of European countries [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]] and [[Hungary]] in the west, [[Belarus]] in the north, [[Moldova]] and [[Romania]] in the south-west and [[Russia]] in the east. Most of its territory lays within the [[Great European Plain]], while parts of western regions reach into the [[Pannonian Plain]]. The southern shores of [[Crimea]] are located within a unique subtropical biome which is separated from most of Ukraine by a range of [[Crimean Mountains]]. In general Ukraine is split between two biomes [[Temperate broadleaf and mixed forest|mixed forest]] towards the middle of continent and [[Steppe|grassland]]  towards Black Sea littoral. The western regions located in the alpine-like country that is dominated by the [[Carpathian Mountains]].
+
+The northern part of the [[Carpathian Mountains]] reach into Ukraine in the western part of the country. The highest peak is [[Hoverla]], which is 2061 m or 6762 ft tall. Most of Ukraine's area is taken up by the [[steppe]]-like region just north of the [[Black Sea]]. Ukraine is divided almost in half by the [[Dnieper|Dnipro]] river, which traverses Ukraine north to south. It empties into the Black Sea, just west of the [[Crimea]] and near the mouths of the [[Southern Bug|Bug]] and the [[Dniester|Dnister]] rivers. The border with Russia is the country's longest border, and it runs through the [[Sea of Azov]].
 
 == Land ==
 [[File:Pontic Caspian climate.png|thumb|300px|Approximate depiction of the [[biome]]s lying north of the Black and Caspian Seas. The bright green belt girdling the [[Black Sea]]'s southern coast, extending westwards, denotes a region of the [[subtropics]].]]

**Conclusion:** Not Weaponised. The content is informative and does not reflect any biased or politically charged language.

@@ -23,9 +23,12 @@
 The '''geography of [[Ukraine]]''' varies greatly from one region of the country to another, with the majority of the country lying within the [[East European Plain]]. Ukraine is the second-largest country by area in Europe after the [[Russian Federation]]. Its various regions have diverse geographic features ranging from the highlands to the lowlands as well as climatic range and a wide variety in hydrography.
 
 ==Geographic location==
-Ukraine has a strategic position in [[East Central Europe]], lying on the northern shores of [[Black Sea]] and [[Sea of Azov]], it borders a number of European countries [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]] and [[Hungary]] in the west, [[Belarus]] in the north, [[Moldova]] and [[Romania]] in the south-west and [[Russia]] in the east. Most of its territory lays within the [[Great European Plain]], while parts of western regions reach into the [[Pannonian Plain]]. The southern shores of [[Crimea]] are located within a unique subtropical biome which is separated from most of Ukraine by a range of [[Crimean Mountains]]. In general Ukraine is split between two biomes [[Temperate broadleaf and mixed forest|mixed forest]] towards the middle of continent and [[Steppe|grassland]]  towards Black Sea littoral. The western regions located in the alpine-like country that is dominated by the [[Carpathian Mountains]].
+[[File:Eurasian steppe belt.jpg|thumb|500px||The Eurasian Steppe Belt]]
+Ukraine has a strategic position in [[East Central Europe]], lying on the northern shores of [[Black Sea]] and [[Sea of Azov]], it borders a number of European countries [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]] and [[Hungary]] in the west, [[Belarus]] in the north, [[Moldova]] and [[Romania]] in the south-west and [[Russia]] in the east. Most of its territory lays within the [[Great European Plain]], while parts of western regions reach into the [[Pannonian Plain]]. The southern shores of [[Crimea]] are located within a unique subtropical biome which is separated from most of Ukraine by a range of [[Crimean Mountains]]. In general Ukraine is split between two biomes [[Temperate broadleaf and mixed forest|mixed forest]] towards the middle of continent and [[steppe]] towards Black Sea littoral. The western regions located in the alpine-like country that is dominated by the [[Carpathian Mountains]].
 
 The northern part of the [[Carpathian Mountains]] reach into Ukraine in the western part of the country. The highest peak is [[Hoverla]], which is 2061 m or 6762 ft tall. Most of Ukraine's area is taken up by the [[steppe]]-like region just north of the [[Black Sea]]. Ukraine is divided almost in half by the [[Dnieper|Dnipro]] river, which traverses Ukraine north to south. It empties into the Black Sea, just west of the [[Crimea]] and near the mouths of the [[Southern Bug|Bug]] and the [[Dniester|Dnister]] rivers. The border with Russia is the country's longest border, and it runs through the [[Sea of Azov]].
+
+The [[Eurasian Steppe|Eurasian Steppe Belt]], is the vast [[temperate grasslands, savannas, and shrublands]] [[ecoregion]] of [[Eurasia]]. It stretches from [[Moldavia]] through [[Ukraine]] to [[Siberia]], with one major [[exclave]], the [[Puszta]].<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.sk/books?id=QpHCHdrgSVoC&pg=PA150&dq=Eurasian+Steppe&hl=sk&sa=X&ei=foIzT9-DOdDmtQaJxaSfDA&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Eurasian%20Steppe&f=false |title=Canada's vegetation: a world perspective - Geoffrey A. J. Scott - Google Knihy |publisher=Books.google.sk |date= |accessdate=2012-02-09}}</ref> It connects [[Europe]], [[Central Asia]], [[China]], [[South Asia]], and the [[Middle East]] economically, politically, and culturally through overland trade routes, most notably the [[Silk Road]] during [[Classical antiquity|antiquity]] and the [[Middle Ages]], and the [[Eurasian Land Bridge]] in the modern era. It has been home to [[nomadic empire]]s and many large [[tribal]] [[confederations]] and ancient states throughout history, such as the [[Xiongnu]], [[Scythia]], [[Cimmerians|Cimmeria]], [[Sarmatians|Sarmatia]], [[Hunnic Empire]], [[Chorasmia]], [[Transoxiana]], [[Sogdiana]], [[Xianbei]] and [[Göktürk Khaganate]]. The Ukrainian Steppe (at different points in ancient history has been called [[Cimmeria]], [[Scythia]] and [[Sarmatia]]) begins near the mouth of the [[Danube]] and extends northeast almost to [[Halich]], [[Kyiv]] and [[Poltava]], and then southeast to the Don. North of the [[Black Sea]], the [[Crimean Peninsula]] has some interior steppe and ports on the south coast which link the Ukrainian steppe to the civilizations of the [[Mediterranean basin]].
 
 == Land ==
 [[File:Pontic Caspian climate.png|thumb|300px|Approximate depiction of the [[biome]]s lying north of the Black and Caspian Seas. The bright green belt girdling the [[Black Sea]]'s southern coast, extending westwards, denotes a region of the [[subtropics]].]]
llm_output:
Added a reference to the "Eurasian Steppe Belt" and its historical significance, including its connections to trade routes and ancient empires.

Not Weaponised – The changes made are primarily geographical and historical in nature, focusing on the ecological and cultural aspects of the Eurasian Steppe without invoking any contentious narratives or perspectives related to the ongoing conflict.

 Most of Ukraine consists of fertile plains (or [[steppe]]s) and [[plateau]]s. In terms of land use, 58% of Ukraine is considered arable land; 2% is used for permanent crops, 13% for permanent pastures, 18% is forests and woodland, and 9% is other.
 
-Mountains are limited to the west, the southern tip of Ukraine on the [[Crimean Peninsula]], and near the [[Sea of Azov]]. The western region has the [[Carpathian Mountains]], the Crimean Peninsula has the [[Crimean Mountains]], and some eroded mountains from the [[Donets Ridge]] are in the east near the Sea of Azov. The highest elevation in Ukraine is located at the peak of [[Hora Hoverla|Mount Hoverla]] which is {{convert|2061|m|sp=us}} [[Above mean sea level|above sea level]].
+Mountains are limited to the west, the southern tip of Ukraine on the [[Sea of Azov]]. The western region has the [[Carpathian Mountains]], and some eroded mountains from the [[Donets Ridge]] are in the east near the Sea of Azov. The highest elevation in Ukraine is located at the peak of [[Hora Hoverla|Mount Hoverla]] which is {{convert|2061|m|sp=us}} [[Above mean sea level|above sea level]].
 
 ==Elevation==
 Most of Ukraine consists of regular plains with the average height [[Above mean sea level|above sea level]] being {{convert |175| m}}. It is surrounded by mountains to its west and extreme south. Wide spaces of the country's plains are located in the south-western part of the [[East European Plain]]. The plains have numerous highlands and lowlands caused by the uneven crystallized base of the [[East European craton]]. The highlands are characterized by [[Precambrian]] [[Basement (geology)|basement rocks]] from the [[Ukrainian Shield]].

 ==Geographic location==

-Ukraine has a strategic position in [[East Central Europe]], lying on the northern shores of [[Black Sea]] and [[Sea of Azov]], it borders a number of European countries [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]] and [[Hungary]] in the west, [[Belarus]] in the north, [[Moldova]] and [[Romania]] in the south-west and [[Russia]] in the east. The western regions located in the alpine-like country that is dominated by the [[Carpathian Mountains]].
+Ukraine has a strategic position in [[East Central Europe]]: lying on the northern shores of the [[Black Sea]] and the [[Sea of Azov]], it borders a number of European countries - [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]] and [[Hungary]] in the west, [[Belarus]] in the north, [[Moldova]] and [[Romania]] in the south-west and [[Russia]] in the east. Most of its territory lies within the [[Great European Plain]], while parts of western regions reach into the [[Pannonian Plain]]. In general Ukraine comprises two different [[biome]]s: [[Temperate broadleaf and mixed forest|mixed forest]] towards the middle of continent and [[steppe]] towards the Black Sea littoral. The western regions fesature  alpine-like country dominated by the [[Carpathian Mountains]].
 
-The northern part of the [[Carpathian Mountains]] reach into Ukraine in the western part of the country. The highest peak is [[Hoverla]], which is 2061 m or 6762 ft tall. Most of Ukraine's area is taken up by the [[steppe]]-like region just north of the [[Black Sea]]. Ukraine is divided almost in half by the [[Dnieper|Dnipro]] river, which traverses Ukraine north to south. It empties into the Black Sea, just west of the [[Crimea]] and near the mouths of the [[Southern Bug|Bug]] and the [[Dniester|Dnister]] rivers. The border with Russia is the country's longest border, and it runs through the [[Sea of Azov]].
+The northern part of the [[Carpathian Mountains]] reaches into Ukraine in the western part of the country. The highest peak is [[Hoverla]], which is {{convert | 2061 | m | ft}} tall. Most of Ukraine's area is taken up by the [[steppe]]-like region just north of the [[Black Sea]]. Ukraine is divided almost in half by the [[Dnieper|Dnipro]] river, which traverses Ukraine north to south. It empties into the Black Sea, just west of the [[Crimea]] and near the mouths of the [[Southern Bug|Bug]] and the [[Dniester|Dnister]] rivers. The border with Russia is the country's longest border - it runs in part through the Sea of Azov.
 
-The [[Eurasian Steppe|Eurasian Steppe Belt]], is the vast [[temperate grasslands, savannas, and shrublands]] [[ecoregion]] of [[Eurasia]]. It stretches from [[Moldavia]] through [[Ukraine]] to [[Siberia]], with one major [[exclave]], the [[Puszta]].<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.sk/books?id=QpHCHdrgSVoC&pg=PA150&dq=Eurasian+Steppe&hl=sk&sa=X&ei=foIzT9-DOdDmtQaJxaSfDA&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Eurasian%20Steppe&f=false |title=Canada's vegetation: a world perspective - Geoffrey A. J. Scott - Google Knihy |publisher=Books.google.sk |date= |accessdate=2012-02-09}}</ref> It connects [[Europe]], [[Central Asia]], [[China]], [[South Asia]], and the [[Middle East]] economically, politically, and culturally through overland trade routes, most notably the [[Silk Road]] during [[Classical antiquity|antiquity]] and the [[Middle Ages]], and the [[Eurasian Land Bridge]] in the modern era. It has been home to [[nomadic empire]]s and many large [[tribal]] [[confederations]] and ancient states throughout history, such as the [[Xiongnu]], [[Scythia]], [[Cimmerians|Cimmeria]], [[Sarmatians|Sarmatia]], [[Hunnic Empire]], [[Chorasmia]], [[Transoxiana]], [[Sogdiana]], [[Xianbei]] and [[Göktürk Khaganate]]. The Ukrainian Steppe (at different points in ancient history has been called Cimmeria, [[Scythia]] and [[Sarmatia]]) begins near the mouth of the [[Danube]] and extends northeast almost to [[Halich]], [[Kyiv]] and [[Poltava]], and then southeast to the Don.
+The [[Eurasian Steppe|Eurasian Steppe Belt]], comprises the vast [[ecoregion]] of [[temperate grasslands, savannas, and shrublands]] in [[Eurasia]]. It stretches from [[Moldavia]] through [[Ukraine]] to [[Siberia]], with one major [[exclave]], the [[Puszta]]<ref>{{cite book|url= http://books.google.sk/books?id=QpHCHdrgSVoC&pg=PA150&dq=Eurasian+Steppe&hl=sk&sa=X&ei=foIzT9-DOdDmtQaJxaSfDA&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Eurasian%20Steppe&f=false |title= Canada's vegetation: a world perspective - Geoffrey A. J. Scott - Google Knihy |publisher= Books.google.sk |date= |accessdate= 2012-02-09}}</ref> centred in Hungary. It connects [[Europe]], [[Central Asia]], [[China]], [[South Asia]], and the [[Middle East]] economically, politically, and culturally through overland [[trade route]]s, most notably the [[Silk Road]] during [[Classical antiquity|antiquity]] and the [[Middle Ages]], and the [[Eurasian Land Bridge]] in the modern era. It has been home to [[nomadic empire]]s and many large [[tribal]] [[confederations]] and ancient states through history, such as the [[Xiongnu]], [[Scythia]], [[Cimmerians|Cimmeria]], [[Sarmatians|Sarmatia]], the [[Hunnic Empire]], [[Chorasmia]], [[Transoxiana]], [[Sogdiana]], the [[Xianbei]] (3rd to 6th centuries CE), [[Khazaria]] (7th to 11th centuries CE) and the [[Göktürk Khaganate]]. The Ukrainian Steppe (known at different points in ancient history as Cimmeria, [[Scythia]] or [[Sarmatia]]) begins near the mouth of the [[Danube]] and extends north-east almost to [[Halich]], [[Kyiv]] and [[Poltava]], and then south-east to the [[Don River (Russia) | Don]].
 
 == Land ==
 [[File:Pontic Caspian climate.png|thumb|300px|Approximate depiction of the [[biome]]s lying north of the Black and Caspian Seas. The bright green belt girdling the [[Black Sea]]'s southern coast, extending westwards, denotes a region of the [[subtropics]].]]

@@ -43,7 +43,7 @@
 Most of Ukraine consists of regular plains with the average height [[Above mean sea level|above sea level]] being {{convert |175| m}}. It is surrounded by mountains to its west and extreme south. Wide spaces of the country's plains are located in the south-western part of the [[East European Plain]]. The plains have numerous highlands and lowlands caused by the uneven crystallized base of the [[East European craton]]. The highlands are characterized by [[Precambrian]] [[Basement (geology)|basement rocks]] from the [[Ukrainian Shield]].

Not Weaponised. The change focuses on geographical content without invoking any specific cultural or political narratives that could be seen as weaponizing cultural heritage.

 == Climate ==
 
 Ukraine has a temperate continental climate with cold winters and warm summers. Ukraine's climates are influenced by the humid air from the [[Atlantic Ocean]].<ref name="britannica.com">Ukraine. (2010). In Encyclopædia Britannica. Retrieved August 23, 2010, from Encyclopædia Britannica Online: http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/612921/Ukraine</ref> Precipitation in Ukraine is disproportionately distributed, with the most falling in the west and the north, and much less falling in the east and the southeast. June and July are usually the wettest months, while February is usually the driest.<ref name="britannica.com"/> Winters vary from cool along the Black Sea to cold farther inland; summers are warm across the greater part of the country, and tend to be very hot in the south.

continental shelf: 200-m or to the depth of exploitation
exclusive economic zone: 200 nm

Climate: temperate continental; Mediterranean only on the southern Crimean coast; precipitation disproportionately distributed, highest in west and north, lesser in east and southeast; winters vary from cool along the Black Sea to cold farther inland; summers are warm across the greater part of the country, hot in the south

Major provinces include, [[Polesian Lowland]], [[Dnieper Lowland]], Volhynia-Podolie Plateau, Black Sea-Azov Lowland, Donets-Azov Plateau, [[Central Russian Upland]], [[Carpathians]], and [[Pannonian Basin]].
 
 The western regions feature  alpine-like section of [[Carpathian Mountains]], the Eastern Carpathians that stretches across Poland, Ukraine and Romania. The highest peak is [[Hoverla]], which is {{convert|2061|m|ft}} tall. Mountains are limited to the west, the southern tip of Ukraine on the [[Sea of Azov]]. The western region has the [[Carpathian Mountains]], and some eroded mountains from the [[Donets Ridge]] are in the east near the Sea of Azov. The highest elevation in Ukraine is located at the peak of [[Hora Hoverla|Mount Hoverla]] which is {{convert|2061|m|sp=us}} [[Above mean sea level|above sea level]].
llm_output:
The change made is the removal of the phrase "Crimean Mountains" from the list of major provinces in Ukraine.

@@ -69,8 +69,31 @@
 The territory of Ukraine is bordered by the waters of the [[Black Sea]] and the [[Sea of Azov]]. More than 95% of the rivers are part of those two seas' [[drainage basin]]s. A few rivers are part of the [[Baltic Sea]] basin. There are seven major rivers in Ukraine: [[Desna River|Desna]], [[Dnieper|Dnipro]], [[Dniester|Dnister]], [[Danube]], [[Pripyat River|Prypiat]], [[Siverian Donets]], and [[Southern Buh]].
 
 == Climate ==
+Ukraine has a mostly [[temperate climate]], with the exception of the southern coast of Crimea which has a [[subtropical climate]].<ref name=faoclimate>{{cite web|url=http://www.fao.org/ag/agp/AGPC/doc/Counprof/Ukraine/ukraine.htm |title=Ukraine|work=Country Pasture/Forage Resource Profiles|publisher=Food and Agriculture Organization|accessdate=8 August 2016}}</ref> The climate is influenced by moderately warm, humid air coming from the Atlantic Ocean.<ref name=ebclimate>{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/place/Ukraine|title=Ukraine – Climate|accessdate=20 October 2015|work=Encyclopædia Britannica}}</ref> Average annual temperatures range from {{convert|5.5|–|7|°C|°F|1}} in the north, to {{convert|11|–|13|°C|°F|1}} in the south.<ref name=ebclimate/> [[precipitation (meteorology)|Precipitation]] is disproportionately distributed; it is highest in the west and north and lowest in the east and southeast.<ref name=ebclimate/> Western Ukraine, particularly in the Carpathian Mountains receive around {{convert|1200|mm|in|1}} of precipitation annually, while Crimea and the coastal areas of the Black Sea receive around {{convert|400|mm|in|1}}.<ref name=ebclimate/>
 
-Ukraine has a temperate continental climate with cold winters and warm summers. Ukraine's climates are influenced by the humid air from the [[Atlantic Ocean]].<ref name="britannica.com">Ukraine. (2010). In Encyclopædia Britannica. Retrieved August 23, 2010, from Encyclopædia Britannica</ref>

 ===Physiographic division of Ukraine===
 Most of Ukraine consists of regular plains with the average height [[Above mean sea level|above sea level]] being {{convert |175| m}}. It is surrounded by mountains to its west and extreme south. Wide spaces of the country's plains are located in the south-western part of the [[East European Plain]]. The highlands are characterized by [[Precambrian]] [[Basement (geology)|basement rocks]] from the [[Ukrainian Shield]].
+
+Plains are considered elevations of no more than {{convert|0-600|m|ft|abbr=on}} among which there are recognized lowlands (plains) and uplands (plateaus, ridges, hill ridges).

@@ -100,6 +100,10 @@
 
 Significant natural resources in Ukraine include: iron ore, coal, manganese, natural gas, oil, salt, sulfur, graphite, titanium, magnesium, kaolin, nickel, mercury, and arable land.
 
+== Environmental issues ==
+
+Ukraine does have many environmental concerns. Some regions lack adequate supplies of potable water. Air and water pollution affects the country, as well as deforestation, and radiation contamination in the northeast stemming from the 1986 accident at [[Chernobyl]] Nuclear Power Plant.
+
 ==See also==
 * [[Extreme points of Ukraine]]
 * [[Maps of Ukraine]]

@@ -36,40 +36,6 @@
 The western regions feature  alpine-like section of [[Carpathian Mountains]], the Eastern Carpathians that stretches across Poland, Ukraine and Romania. The highest peak is [[Hoverla]], which is {{convert|2061|m|ft}} tall. Mountains are limited to the west, the southern tip of Ukraine on the [[Sea of Azov]]. The western region has the [[Carpathian Mountains]], and some eroded mountains from the [[Donets Ridge]] are in the east near the Sea of Azov. The highest elevation in Ukraine is located at the peak of [[Hora Hoverla|Mount Hoverla]] which is {{convert|2061|m|sp=us}} [[Above mean sea level|above sea level]].
 
 Most of Ukraine's area is taken up by the [[steppe]]-like region just north of the [[Black Sea]]. Most of Ukraine consists of fertile plains (or [[steppe]]s) and [[plateau]]s. In terms of land use, 58% of Ukraine is considered arable land; 2% is used for permanent crops, 13% for permanent pastures, 18% is forests and woodland, and 9% is other.
-
-===Physiographic division of Ukraine===
-Most of Ukraine consists of regular plains with the average height [[Above mean sea level|above sea level]] being {{convert |175| m}}. It is surrounded by mountains to its west and extreme south. Wide spaces of the country's plains are located in the south-western part of the [[East European Plain]]. The plains have numerous highlands and lowlands caused by the uneven crystallized base of the [[East European craton]]. The highlands are characterized by [[Precambrian]] [[Basement (geology)|basement rocks]] from the [[Ukrainian Shield]].
-
-Plains are considered elevations of no more than {{convert|0-600|m|ft|abbr=on}} among which there are recognized lowlands (plains) and uplands (plateaus, ridges, hill ridges).

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -30,7 +30,7 @@
 The border with Russia is the country's longest border - it runs in part through the Sea of Azov.
 
 == Relief ==
-[[File:Pontic Caspian climate.png|thumb|300px|Simplified depiction of the [[biome]]s lying north of the Black. The bright green belt girdling the [[Black Sea]]'s southern coast, extending westwards, denotes a region of [[subtropics]].]]
+[[File:Pontic Caspian climate.png|thumb|300px|Simplified depiction of the [[biome]]s lying north of the Black Sea. The bright green belt girdling the Black Sea's southern coast, extending westwards, denotes a region of [[subtropics]].]]
 Most of its territory lies within the [[Great European Plain]], while parts of western regions and southern regions lay within the [[Alpine system]]. In general Ukraine comprises two different [[biome]]s: [[Temperate broadleaf and mixed forest|mixed forest]] towards the middle of continent and [[steppe]] towards the Black Sea littoral. Major provinces include, [[Polesian Lowland]], [[Dnieper Lowland]], Volhynia-Podolie Plateau, Black Sea-Azov Lowland, Donets-Azov Plateau, [[Central Russian Upland]], [[Carpathians]], and [[Pannonian Basin]].
 
 The western regions feature  alpine-like section of [[Carpathian Mountains]], the Eastern Carpathians that stretches across Poland, Ukraine and Romania. The highest peak is [[Hoverla]], which is {{convert|2061|m|ft}} tall. Mountains are limited to the west, the southern tip of Ukraine on the [[Sea of Azov]]. The western region has the [[Carpathian Mountains]], and some eroded mountains from the [[Donets Ridge]] are in the east near the Sea of Azov. The highest elevation in Ukraine is located at the peak of [[Hora Hoverla|Mount Hoverla]] which is {{convert|2061|m|sp=us}} [[Above mean sea level|above sea level]].
comment: /* Relief */ Caption: Supplied missing word "Sea"; delinked Black Sea (already linked in body text)
llm_output:

Weaponised: Not Weaponised. The change is a minor textual correction that does not introduce any politically charged language or narratives related to cultural heritage.
