 ==Geographic location==
 {{see also|Eurasian Steppe}}
-Ukraine has a strategic position in [[Eastern Europe]]: lying on the northern shores of the [[Black Sea]] and the [[Sea of Azov]], it borders a number of European countries - [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]] and [[Hungary]] in the west, [[Belarus]] in the north, [[Moldova]] and [[Romania]] in the south-west and [[Russia]] in the east. +Ukraine has a strategic position in [[Eastern Europe]]: lying on the northern shores of the [[Black Sea]] and the [[Sea of Azov]], it borders a number of European countries - [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]] and [[Hungary]] in the west, [[Belarus]] in the north, [[Moldova]] and [[Romania]] in the south-west and [[Russia]] in the east. The total geographic area of Ukraine is {{convert|603550|km2|sp=us}}. The Ukraine has an [[Exclusive Economic Zone]] of {{convert|147,318|km2|mi2|abbr=on}} in the [[Black Sea]].
 
 The land border of Ukraine totals {{convert|4558|km|sp=us}}. The border lengths with each country are: [[Belarus]] {{convert |891|km|sp=us}}, [[Hungary]] {{convert |103|km|sp=us}}, [[Moldova]] {{convert |939|km|sp=us}}, [[Poland]] {{convert |428|km|sp=us}}, [[Romania]] {{convert |169|km|sp=us}} on the south and {{convert |362|km|sp=us}} on the west, [[Russia]] {{convert |1974|km|sp=us}}, and [[Slovakia]] {{convert |90|km|sp=us}}. Ukraine is also bordered by {{convert|3783|km|sp=us}} of coastline. The border with Russia is the country's longest border - it runs in part through the Sea of Azov.

@@ -102,10 +102,10 @@
 The territory of Ukraine is bordered by the waters of the [[Black Sea]] and the [[Sea of Azov]]. More than 95% of the rivers are part of those two seas' [[drainage basin]]s. A few rivers are part of the [[Baltic Sea]] basin. There are seven major rivers in Ukraine: [[Desna River|Desna]], [[Dnieper|Dnipro]], [[Dniester|Dnister]], [[Danube]], [[Pripyat River|Prypiat]], [[Siverian Donets]], and [[Southern Buh]].
 
 == Climate ==
-Ukraine has a mostly [[temperate climate]], with the exception of the southern coast of Crimea which has a [[subtropical climate]].<ref name=faoclimate>{{cite web|url=http://www.fao.org/ag/agp/AGPC/doc/Counprof/Ukraine/ukraine.htm |title=Ukraine|work=Country Pasture/Forage Resource Profiles|publisher=Food and Agriculture Organization|accessdate=8 August 2016}}</ref> The climate is influenced by moderately warm, humid air coming from the Atlantic Ocean.<ref name=ebclimate>{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/place/Ukraine|title=Ukraine – Climate|accessdate=20 October 2015|work=Encyclopædia Britannica}}</ref> Average annual temperatures range from {{convert|5.5|–|7|°C|°F|1}} in the north, to {{convert|11|–|13|°C|°F|1}} in the south.<ref name=ebclimate/> [[precipitation (meteorology)|Precipitation]] is disproportionately distributed; it is highest in the west and north and lowest in the east and southeast.<ref name=ebclimate/> Western Ukraine, particularly in the Carpathian Mountains receive around {{convert|1200|mm|in|1}} of precipitation annually, while Crimea and the coastal areas of the Black Sea receive around {{convert|400|mm|in|1}}.<ref name=ebclimate/>
+Ukraine has a mostly [[temperate climate]], with the exception of the southern coast of Crimea which has a [[subtropical climate]].<ref name=faoclimate>{{cite web|url=http://www.fao.org/ag/agp/AGPC/doc/Counprof/Ukraine/ukraine.htm |title=Ukraine|work=Country Pasture/Forage Resource Profiles|publisher=Food and Agriculture Organization|access-date=8 August 2016}}</ref> The climate is influenced by moderately warm, humid air coming from the Atlantic Ocean.<ref name=ebclimate>{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/place/Ukraine|title=Ukraine – Climate|access-date=20 October 2015|work=Encyclopædia Britannica}}</ref> Average annual temperatures range from {{convert|5.5|–|7|°C|°F|1}} in the north, to {{convert|11|–|13|°C|°F|1}} in the south.<ref name=ebclimate/> [[precipitation (meteorology)|Precipitation]] is disproportionately distributed; it is highest in the west and north and lowest in the east and southeast.<ref name=ebclimate/> Western Ukraine, particularly in the Carpathian Mountains receive around {{convert|1200|mm|in|1}} of precipitation annually, while Crimea and the coastal areas of the Black Sea receive around {{convert|400|mm|in|1}}.<ref name=ebclimate/>

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -52,6 +52,8 @@
 Ukraine has a strategic position in [[Eastern Europe]]: lying on the northern shores of the [[Black Sea]] and the [[Sea of Azov]], it borders a number of European countries - [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]] and [[Hungary]] in the west, [[Belarus]] in the north, [[Moldova]] and [[Romania]] in the south-west and [[Russia]] in the east. The total geographic area of Ukraine is {{convert|603550|km2|sp=us}}. Ukraine has an [[Exclusive Economic Zone]] of {{convert|147,318|km2|mi2|abbr=on}} in the [[Black Sea]].
 
 The land border of Ukraine totals {{convert|6993|km|sp=us}}.<ref>https://web.archive.org/web/20071206030446/http://www.pvu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=47129&cat_id=46429</ref> The border lengths with each country are: [[Belarus]] {{convert |891|km|sp=us}}, [[Hungary]] {{convert |103|km|sp=us}}, [[Moldova]] {{convert |939|km|sp=us}}, [[Poland]] {{convert |428|km|sp=us}}, [[Romania]] {{convert |169|km|sp=us}} on the south and {{convert |362|km|sp=us}} on the west, [[Russia]] {{convert |1974|km|sp=us}}, and [[Slovakia]] {{convert |90|km|sp=us}}. Ukraine is also bordered by {{convert|3783|km|sp=us}} of coastline. The border with Russia is the country's longest border - it runs in part through the Sea of Azov.
+
+The village of [[Veľké Slemence|Vel'ké Slemence]] (Ukrainian: [[Mali Slementsi/Малі Селменці]]) (Hungarian: Szelmenc) is an [[anomaly]], as it's a village with a majority of Hungarians, but it's split between [[Geography of Slovakia|Slovakia]] and [[Ukraine]].
 
 == Relief ==
 [[File:Pontic Caspian climate.png|thumb|300px|Simplified depiction of the [[biome]]s lying north of the Black Sea. The bright green belt girdling the Black Sea's southern coast, extending westwards, denotes a region of [[subtropics]].]]
llm_output:
Added information about the village of Vel'ké Slemence, highlighting its unique demographic and geographical situation.

Not Weaponised – The addition provides factual information about a specific village without employing any charged language or narratives that could be seen as weaponizing cultural heritage.

@@ -57,7 +57,7 @@
 [[File:Pontic Caspian climate.png|thumb|300px|Simplified depiction of the [[biome]]s lying north of the Black Sea. The bright green belt girdling the Black Sea's southern coast, extending westwards, denotes a region of [[subtropics]].]]
 Most of its territory lies within the [[Great European Plain]], while parts of western regions and southern regions lay within the [[Alpine system]]. In general Ukraine comprises two different [[biome]]s: [[Temperate broadleaf and mixed forest|mixed forest]] towards the middle of continent and [[steppe]] towards the Black Sea littoral. Major provinces include, [[Polesian Lowland]], [[Dnieper Lowland]], Volhynia-Podolie Plateau, Black Sea-Azov Lowland, Donets-Azov Plateau, [[Central Russian Upland]], [[Carpathians]], and [[Pannonian Basin]].
 
-The western regions feature  alpine-like section of [[Carpathian Mountains]], the Eastern Carpathians that stretches across Poland, Ukraine and Romania. The highest peak is [[Hoverla]], which is {{convert|2061|m|ft}} tall. Mountains are limited to the west, the southern tip of Ukraine on the [[Sea of Azov]]. The western region has the [[Carpathian Mountains]], and some eroded mountains from the [[Donets Ridge]] are in the east near the Sea of Azov. The highest elevation in Ukraine is located at the peak of [[Hora Hoverla|Mount Hoverla]] which is {{convert|2061|m|sp=us}} [[Above mean sea level|above sea level]].

The highest peak is [[Hoverla]], which is {{convert|2061|m|ft}} tall. Mountains are limited to the west, the southern tip of Ukraine on the [[Sea of Azov]]. The western region has the [[Carpathian Mountains]], and some eroded mountains from the [[Donets Ridge]] are in the east near the Sea of Azov. The highest elevation in Ukraine is located at the peak of [[Hora Hoverla|Mount Hoverla]] which is {{convert|2061|m|sp=us}} [[Above mean sea level|above sea level]].
 
 Most of Ukraine's area is taken up by the [[steppe]]-like region just north of the [[Black Sea]]. Most of Ukraine consists of fertile plains (or [[steppe]]s) and [[plateau]]s. In terms of land use, 58% of Ukraine is considered arable land; 2% is used for permanent crops, 13% for permanent pastures, 18% is forests and woodland, and 9% is other.
llm_output:
Changed "alpine-like section" to "an alpine-like section" in the description of the Carpathian Mountains.

Map references: Commonwealth of Independent States

total: 603,700 sq km

continental shelf: 200-m or to the depth of exploitation
exclusive economic zone: 200 nm
territorial sea: 12 nm

Climate: temperate continental; Mediterranean only on the southern Crimean coast; precipitation disproportionately distributed, highest in west and north, lesser in east and southeast; winters vary from cool along the Black Sea to cold farther inland; summers are warm across the greater part of the country, hot in the south

Elevation extremes:

 The territory of Ukraine is bordered by the waters of the [[Black Sea]] and the [[Sea of Azov]]. More than 95% of the rivers are part of those two seas' [[drainage basin]]s. A few rivers are part of the [[Baltic Sea]] basin. There are seven major rivers in Ukraine: [[Desna River|Desna]], [[Dnieper|Dnipro]], [[Dniester|Dnister]], [[Danube]], [[Pripyat River|Prypiat]], [[Siverian Donets]], and [[Southern Buh]].
 
 == Climate ==
-Ukraine has a mostly [[temperate climate]], with the exception of the southern coast of Crimea which has a [[subtropical climate]].<ref name=faoclimate>{{cite web|url=http://www.fao.org/ag/agp/AGPC/doc/Counprof/Ukraine/ukraine.htm |title=Ukraine|work=Country Pasture/Forage Resource Profiles|publisher=Food and Agriculture Organization|access-date=8 August 2016}}</ref> The climate is influenced by moderately warm, humid air coming from the Atlantic Ocean.<ref name=ebclimate>{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/place/Ukraine|title=Ukraine – Climate|access-date=20 October 2015|work=Encyclopædia Britannica}}</ref> Average annual temperatures range from {{convert|5.5|–|7|°C|°F|1}} in the north, to {{convert|11|–|13|°C|°F|1}} in the south.<ref name=ebclimate/> [[precipitation (meteorology)|Precipitation]] is disproportionately distributed; it is highest in the west and north and lowest in the east and southeast.<ref name=ebclimate/> Western Ukraine, particularly in the Carpathian Mountains receive around {{convert|1200|mm|in|1}} of precipitation annually, while Crimea and the coastal areas of the Black Sea receive around {{convert|400|mm|in|1}}.<ref name=ebclimate/>

@@ -63,11 +63,13 @@
 
 Most of Ukraine's area is taken up by the [[steppe]]-like region just north of the [[Black Sea]]. Most of Ukraine consists of fertile plains (or [[steppe]]s) and [[plateau]]s. In terms of land use, 58% of Ukraine is considered arable land; 2% is used for permanent crops, 13% for permanent pastures, 18% is forests and woodland, and 9% is other.
 
-evel]] being {{convert |175| m}}. It is surrounded by mountains to its west and extreme south. Wide spaces of the country's plains are located in the south-western part of the [[East European Plain]]. The plains have numerous highlands and lowlands caused by the uneven crystallized base of the [[East European craton]]. The highlands are characterized by [[Precambrian]] [[Basement (geology)|basement rocks]] from the [[Ukrainian Shield]].
+===Physiographic division of Ukraine===
+Most of Ukraine consists of regular plains with the average height [[Above mean sea level|above sea level]] being {{convert |175| m}}. It is surrounded by mountains to its west and extreme south. Wide spaces of the country's plains are located in the south-western part of the [[East European Plain]]. The plains have numerous highlands and lowlands caused by the uneven crystallized base of the [[East European craton]]. The highlands are characterized by [[Precambrian]] [[Basement (geology)|basement rocks]] from the [[Ukrainian Shield]].
 
 Plains are considered elevations of no more than {{convert|0-600|m|ft|abbr=on}} among which there are recognized lowlands (plains) and uplands (plateaus, ridges, hill ridges).
 
 ====[[Great European Plain]] (subregion [[East European Plain]])====
+* [[Volhynia-Podillia Upland]] (Volhynia-Podillia Plateau)
 ** Volhynian Upland
 ** [[Podolian Upland]]
 * Small Polesia Plain

 == Relief ==
 [[File:Pontic Caspian climate.png|thumb|300px|Simplified depiction of the [[biome]]s lying north of the Black Sea. The bright green belt girdling the Black Sea's southern coast, extending westwards, denotes a region of [[subtropics]].]]
-Most of its territory lies within the [[Great European Plain]], while parts of western regions and southern regions lay within the [[Alpine system]]. In general Ukraine comprises two different [[biome]]s: [[Temperate broadleaf and mixed forest|mixed forest]] towards the middle of continent and [[steppe]] towards the Black Sea littoral. Major provinces include, [[Polesian Lowland]], [[Dnieper Lowland]], Volhynia-Podolie Plateau, Black Sea-Azov Lowland, Donets-Azov Plateau, [[Central Russian Upland]], [[Carpathians]], and [[Pannonian Basin]].
+Most of its territory lies within the [[Great European Plain]], while parts of western regions and southern regions lay within the [[Alpine system]]. In general Ukraine comprises two different [[biome]]s: [[Temperate broadleaf and mixed forest|mixed forest]] towards the middle of the continent, and [[steppe]] towards the Black Sea littoral. Major provinces include, [[Polesian Lowland]], [[Dnieper Lowland]], Volhynia-Podolie Plateau, Black Sea-Azov Lowland, Donets-Azov Plateau, [[Central Russian Upland]], [[Carpathians]], and [[Pannonian Basin]].
 
 The western regions feature an alpine-like section of [[Carpathian Mountains]], the Eastern Carpathians that stretches across Poland, Ukraine and Romania. The highest peak is [[Hoverla]], which is {{convert|2061|m|ft}} tall. Mountains are limited to the west, the southern tip of Ukraine on the [[Sea of Azov]]. The western region has the [[Carpathian Mountains]], and some eroded mountains from the [[Donets Ridge]] are in the east near the Sea of Azov. The highest elevation in Ukraine is located at the peak of [[Hora Hoverla|Mount Hoverla]] which is {{convert|2061|m|sp=us}} [[Above mean sea level|above sea level]].

 |+Average daily maximum and minimum temperatures for the seven largest cities in Ukraine<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.weatherbase.com/weather/city.php3?c=UA&name=Ukraine|title=Ukraine climate information|publisher=Weatherbase|access-date=February 2, 2016}}</ref>
 |-
@@ -129,6 +127,9 @@
 |-
 |[[Lviv]] || 24/13 || 75/56 || -1/-8 || 32/21
 |}
+Ukraine has a mostly [[temperate climate]], with the exception of the southern coast of Crimea which has a [[subtropical climate]].<ref name=faoclimate>{{cite web|url=http://www.fao.org/ag/agp/AGPC/doc/Counprof/Ukraine/ukraine.htm |title=Ukraine|work=Country Pasture/Forage Resource Profiles|publisher=Food and Agriculture Organization|access-date=8 August 2016}}</ref> The climate is influenced by moderately warm, humid air coming from the Atlantic Ocean.<ref name=ebclimate>{{cite encyclopedia|url=http://www.britannica.com/place/Ukraine|title=Ukraine – Climate|access-date=20 October 2015|encyclopedia=Encyclopædia Britannica}}</ref> Average annual temperatures range from {{convert|5.5|–|7|°C|°F|1}} in the north, to {{convert|11|–|13|°C|°F|1}} in the south.<ref name=ebclimate/> [[precipitation (meteorology)|Precipitation]] is disproportionately distributed; it is highest in the west and north and lowest in the east and southeast.<ref name=ebclimate/> Western Ukraine, particularly in the Carpathian Mountains receive around {{convert|1200|mm|in|1}} of precipitation annually, while Crimea and the coastal areas of the Black Sea receive around {{convert|400|mm|in|1}}.<ref name=ebclimate/>
+
+Water availability from the major river basins is expected to decrease, especially in summer. This poses risks to the agricultural sector.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Didovets |first=Iulii |last2=Krysanova |first2=Valentina |last3=Hattermann |first3=Fred Fokko |last4=del Rocío Rivas López |first4=María |last5=Snizhko |first5=Sergiy |last6=Müller Schmied |first6=Hannes |date=2020-12-01 |title=Climate change impact on water availability of main river basins in Ukraine |url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2214581820302354 |journal=Journal of Hydrology: Regional Studies |language=en |volume=32 |pages=100761 |doi=10.1016/j.ejrh.2020.100761 |issn=2214-5818}}</ref> The negative impacts of [[climate change]] on agriculture are mostly felt in the south of the country, which is characterised by a [[steppe]] climate. In the north, some crops may be able to benefit from a longer growing season.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Skrypnyk |first=Andriy |last2=Zhemoyda |first2=Oleksandr |last3=Klymenko |first3=Nataliia |last4=Galaieva |first4=Liudmyla |last5=Koval |first5=Tatiana |date=2021-03-01 |title=Econometric Analysis of the Impact of Climate Change on the Sustainability of Agricultural Production in Ukraine |url=http://www.jeeng.net/Econometric-Analysis-of-the-Impact-of-Climate-Change-on-the-Sustainability-of-Agricultural,132945,0,2.html |journal=Journal of Ecological Engineering |volume=22 |issue=3 |pages=275–288 |doi=10.12911/22998993/132945 |issn=2299-8993}}</ref> The world bank stated that Ukraine is highly vulnerable to climate change.<ref>{{cite web |title=World Bank Climate Change Knowledge Portal |url=https://climateknowledgeportal.worldbank.org/country/ukraine |website=climateknowledgeportal.worldbank.org |language=en}}</ref>
 
 == Natural resources ==

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -45,7 +45,7 @@
 The '''geography of Ukraine''' varies greatly from one region of the country to another, with the majority of the country lying within the [[East European Plain]]. [[Ukraine]] is the second-largest country by area in Europe (after the [[Russian Federation]]). Its various regions have diverse geographic features ranging from highlands to lowlands, as well as climatic range and a wide variety in hydrography.
 
 ==Geographic location==
-{{see also|Eurasian Steppe}}
+{{see also|Eurasian Steppe}}{{More citations needed section|date=February 2022}}
 Ukraine has a strategic position in [[Eastern Europe]]: lying on the northern shores of the [[Black Sea]] and the [[Sea of Azov]], it borders a number of European countries - [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]] and [[Hungary]] in the west, [[Belarus]] in the north, [[Moldova]] and [[Romania]] in the south-west and [[Russia]] in the east. The total geographic area of Ukraine is {{convert|603550|km2|sp=us}}. Ukraine has an [[Exclusive Economic Zone]] of {{convert|147,318|km2|mi2|abbr=on}} in the [[Black Sea]].
 
 The land border of Ukraine totals {{convert|6993|km|sp=us}}.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pvu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=47129&cat_id=46429 |title=Archived copy |website=www.pvu.gov.ua |access-date=11 January 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071206030446/http://www.pvu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=47129&cat_id=46429 |archive-date=6 December 2007 |url-status=dead}}</ref> The border lengths with each country are: [[Belarus]] {{convert |891|km|sp=us}}, [[Hungary]] {{convert |103|km|sp=us}}, [[Moldova]] {{convert |939|km|sp=us}}, [[Poland]] {{convert |428|km|sp=us}}, [[Romania]] {{convert |169|km|sp=us}} on the south and {{convert |362|km|sp=us}} on the west, [[Russia]] {{convert |1974|km|sp=us}}, and [[Slovakia]] {{convert |90|km|sp=us}}. Ukraine is also bordered by {{convert|3783|km|sp=us}} of coastline. The border with Russia is the country's longest border - it runs in part through the Sea of Azov.
llm_output:
Changed the section header to include a citation request: "Geographic location" now has a "More citations needed" tag.

Not Weaponised. The change is a standard editorial request for citations and does not introduce any weaponised language or narratives.

 == Relief ==
-[[File:Ukraine topo en.jpg|thumb|500px|Relief map]]
+[[File:Topographic map of Ukraine.svg|thumb|350px|Relief map of Ukraine]]

 Most of its territory lies within the [[Great European Plain]], while parts of western regions and southern regions lay within the [[Alpine system]]. In general Ukraine comprises two different [[biome]]s: [[Temperate broadleaf and mixed forest|mixed forest]] towards the middle of the continent, and [[steppe]] towards the Black Sea littoral. Major provinces include, [[Polesian Lowland]], [[Dnieper Lowland]], Volhynia-Podolie Plateau, Black Sea-Azov Lowland, Donets-Azov Plateau, [[Central Russian Upland]], [[Carpathians]], and [[Pannonian Basin]].

-The '''geography of Ukraine''' varies greatly from one region of the country to another, with the majority of the country lying within the [[East European Plain]]. [[Ukraine]] is the second-largest country by area in Europe (after the [[Russian Federation]]). Its various regions have diverse geographic features ranging from highlands to lowlands, as well as climatic range and a wide variety in hydrography.
-
-==Geographic location==
-{{see also|Eurasian Steppe}}{{More citations needed section|date=February 2022}}
 Ukraine has a strategic position in [[Eastern Europe]]: lying on the northern shores of the [[Black Sea]] and the [[Sea of Azov]], it borders a number of European countries - [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]] and [[Hungary]] in the west, [[Belarus]] in the north, [[Moldova]] and [[Romania]] in the south-west and [[Russia]] in the east. The total geographic area of Ukraine is {{convert|603550|km2|sp=us}}. Ukraine has an [[Exclusive Economic Zone]] of {{convert|147,318|km2|mi2|abbr=on}} in the [[Black Sea]].
 
 The land border of Ukraine totals {{convert|6993|km|sp=us}}.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pvu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=47129&cat_id=46429 |title=Archived copy |website=www.pvu.gov.ua |access-date=11 January 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071206030446/http://www.pvu.gov.ua/control/uk/publish/article?art_id=47129&cat_id=46429 |archive-date=6 December 2007 |url-status=dead}}</ref> The border lengths with each country are: [[Belarus]] {{convert |891|km|sp=us}}, [[Hungary]] {{convert |103|km|sp=us}}, [[Moldova]] {{convert |939|km|sp=us}}, [[Poland]] {{convert |428|km|sp=us}}, [[Romania]] {{convert |169|km|sp=us}} on the south and {{convert |362|km|sp=us}} on the west, [[Russia]] {{convert |1974|km|sp=us}}, and [[Slovakia]] {{convert |90|km|sp=us}}. Ukraine is also bordered by {{convert|3783|km|sp=us}} of coastline. The border with Russia is the country's longest border - it runs in part through the Sea of Azov.
@@ -53,7 +50,9 @@
 The village of [[Veľké Slemence|Vel'ké Slemence]] (Ukrainian: [[Mali Slementsi/Малі Селменці]]) (Hungarian: Szelmenc) is an anomaly, as it's a village with a majority of Hungarians, but it's split between [[Geography of Slovakia|Slovakia]] and [[Ukraine]].
 
 == Relief ==
-{{More citations needed section|date=February 2022}}[[File:Pontic Caspian climate.png|thumb|300px|Simplified depiction of the [[biome]]s lying north of the Black Sea. The bright green belt girdling the Black Sea's southern coast, extending westwards, denotes a region of [[subtropics]].]]
+{{More citations needed section|date=February 2022}}
+[[File:Ukraine topo en.jpg|thumb|500px|Relief map]]
+[[File:Pontic Caspian climate.png|thumb|300px|Simplified depiction of the [[biome]]s lying north of the Black Sea. The bright green belt girdling the Black Sea's southern coast, extending westwards, denotes a region of [[subtropics]].]]
 Most of its territory lies within the [[Great European Plain]], while parts of western regions and southern regions lay within the [[Alpine system]]. In general Ukraine comprises two different [[biome]]s: [[Temperate broadleaf and mixed forest|mixed forest]] towards the middle of the continent, and [[steppe]] towards the Black Sea littoral. Major provinces include, [[Polesian Lowland]], [[Dnieper Lowland]], Volhynia-Podolie Plateau, Black Sea-Azov Lowland, Donets-Azov Plateau, [[Central Russian Upland]], [[Carpathians]], and [[Pannonian Basin]].
 
 The western regions feature an alpine-like section of [[Carpathian Mountains]], the Eastern Carpathians that stretches across Poland, Ukraine and Romania. The highest peak is [[Hoverla]], which is {{convert|2061|m|ft}} tall. Mountains are limited to the west, the southern tip of Ukraine on the [[Sea of Azov]]. The western region has the [[Carpathian Mountains]], and some eroded mountains from the [[Donets Ridge]] are in the east near the Sea of Azov. The highest elevation in Ukraine is located at the peak of [[Hora Hoverla|Mount Hoverla]] which is {{convert|2061|m|sp=us}} [[Above mean sea level|above sea level]].
@@ -101,6 +100,8 @@
 The territory of Ukraine is bordered by the waters of the [[Black Sea]] and the [[Sea of Azov]]. More than 95% of the rivers are part of those two seas' [[drainage basin]]s. A few rivers are part of the [[Baltic Sea]] basin. There are seven major rivers in Ukraine: [[Desna River|Desna]], [[Dnieper|Dnipro]], [[Dniester|Dnister]], [[Danube]], [[Pripyat River|Prypiat]], [[Siverian Donets]], and [[Southern Buh]].

 |-

@@ -25,6 +25,15 @@
 }}
 
 The '''geography of Ukraine''' varies greatly from one region of the country to another, with the majority of the country lying within the [[East European Plain]]. [[Ukraine]] is the second-largest country by area in Europe (after the [[Russian Federation]]). Its various regions have diverse geographic features ranging from highlands to lowlands, as well as climatic range and a wide variety in hydrography.
+
+[[File:Говерла з Кукула.jpg|thumb|right|A view of [[Ukrainian Carpathian mountains|Carpathian National Park]] and [[Hoverla]] at {{cvt|2061|m}}, the highest mountain in Ukraine]]
+Ukraine is the [[List of European countries by area|second-largest European country]], after Russia.  Lying between latitudes [[44th parallel north|44°]] and [[53rd parallel north|53° N]], and longitudes [[22nd meridian east|22°]] and [[41st meridian east|41° E]]., it is mostly in the [[East European Plain]]. Ukraine covers an area of {{convert|603628|km2}}, with a coastline of {{convert|2782|km}}.<ref name="cia"/> 
+
+The landscape of Ukraine consists mostly of fertile plains (or [[steppes]]) and plateaus, crossed by rivers such as the [[Dnieper River|Dnieper]] ({{lang|uk-Latn|Dnipro}}), [[Seversky Donets]], [[Dniester]] and the [[Southern Bug]] as they flow south into the [[Black Sea]] and the smaller [[Sea of Azov]]. To the southwest, the [[Danube Delta|delta]] of the [[Danube]] forms the border with Romania. Ukraine's various regions have diverse geographic features ranging from the highlands to the lowlands. The country's only mountains are the [[Carpathian Mountains]] in the west, of which the highest is [[Hoverla]] at {{convert|2061|m}}, and the [[Crimean Mountains]], in the extreme south along the coast.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-30093/Ukraine |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080115052701/http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-30093/Ukraine |archive-date=15 January 2008 |title=Ukraine – Relief |access-date=27 December 2007 |website=Encyclopædia Britannica (fee required) |url-status=dead}}</ref>
+
+Ukraine also has a number of highland regions such as the [[Volhynian-Podolian Upland|Volyn-Podillia Upland]] (in the west) and the Near-Dnipro Upland (on the right bank of Dnieper). To the east there are the south-western spurs of the [[Central Russian Upland]] over which runs the border with the Russian Federation. Near the [[Sea of Azov]] can be found the Donets Ridge and the Near Azov Upland. The [[snow melt]] from the mountains feeds the rivers and their [[waterfalls of Ukraine|waterfalls]].
+
+Significant natural resources in Ukraine include iron ore, coal, manganese, natural gas, oil, salt, sulphur, graphite, titanium, magnesium, [[kaolin]], nickel, mercury, timber and an abundance of arable land. Despite this, the country faces a number of major environmental issues such as inadequate supplies of potable water; air and water pollution and deforestation, as well as radiation contamination in the north-east from the [[Chernobyl disaster|1986 accident at the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant]]. [[Hazardous waste|Recycling toxic household waste]]{{Clarify|date=March 2022}} is still in its infancy in Ukraine.<ref>{{cite news |author=Oksana Grytsenko |url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/118498/ |title=Environment suffers from lack of recycling |newspaper=[[Kyiv Post]] |date=9 December 2011|url-status= dead|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120105012539/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/118498/ |archive-date=5 January 2012}}</ref>
 
 ==Geographic location==
 {{see also|Eurasian Steppe}}
comment: copied text from [[Ukraine]] with the idea of possibly excerpting the lead of this article back to there in future. That would allow new editors to edit as the [[Ukraine]] article is very restricted

Not Weaponised. The changes provide factual geographic and environmental information about Ukraine without employing any politically charged language or narratives that could be seen as weaponizing cultural heritage.

 The landscape of Ukraine consists mostly of fertile plains (or [[steppes]]) and plateaus, crossed by rivers such as the [[Dnieper River|Dnieper]] ({{lang|uk-Latn|Dnipro}}), [[Seversky Donets]], [[Dniester]] and the [[Southern Bug]] as they flow south into the [[Black Sea]] and the smaller [[Sea of Azov]]. To the southwest, the [[Danube Delta|delta]] of the [[Danube]] forms the border with Romania. Ukraine's various regions have diverse geographic features ranging from the highlands to the lowlands. The country's only mountains are the [[Carpathian Mountains]] in the west, of which the highest is [[Hoverla]] at {{convert|2061|m}}, and the [[Crimean Mountains]], in the extreme south along the coast.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-30093/Ukraine |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080115052701/http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-30093/Ukraine |archive-date=15 January 2008 |title=Ukraine – Relief |access-date=27 December 2007 |website=Encyclopædia Britannica (fee required) |url-status=dead}}</ref>

 Ukraine also has a number of highland regions such as the [[Volhynian-Podolian Upland|Volyn-Podillia Upland]] (in the west) and the Near-Dnipro Upland (on the right bank of the Dnieper). To the east there are the south-western spurs of the [[Central Russian Upland]], over which runs the border with the Russia. Near the [[Sea of Azov]] can be found the Donets Ridge and the Near Azov Upland. The [[snow melt]] from the mountains feeds the rivers and their [[waterfalls of Ukraine|waterfalls]].
 
-Significant natural resources in Ukraine include iron ore, coal, manganese, natural gas, oil, salt, sulphur, graphite, titanium, magnesium, [[kaolin]], nickel, mercury, timber and an abundance of arable land. +Significant natural resources in Ukraine include lithium,<ref>{{Cite news |last=Tabuchi |first=Hiroko |date=2022-03-02 |title=Before Invasion, Ukraine’s Lithium Wealth Was Drawing Global Attention |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/03/02/climate/ukraine-lithium.html |access-date=2022-03-03 |issn=0362-4331}}</ref> natural gas,<ref name=":0">{{Cite web |title=Mining – UkraineInvest |url=https://ukraineinvest.gov.ua/industries/mining/ |access-date=2022-03-03 |language=en-US}}</ref> [[kaolin]],<ref name=":0" /> timber<ref>{{Cite web |last=Nature |first=Preferred by |title=Ukraine Timber Risk Profile |url=https://preferredbynature.org/sourcinghub/timber/ukraine-timber-risk-profile |access-date=2022-03-03 |website=NEPCon - Preferred by Nature |language=en}}</ref> and an abundance of arable land. Despite this, the country faces a number of major environmental issues such as inadequate supplies of potable water, air and water pollution, deforestation, and radioactive contamination in the north-east from the [[Chernobyl disaster|1986 accident at the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant]].

 The landscape of Ukraine consists mostly of fertile [[steppes]] and plateaus, crossed by rivers such as the [[Dnieper River|Dnieper]], [[Seversky Donets]], [[Dniester]] and the [[Southern Bug]] as they flow south into the [[Black Sea]] and the smaller [[Sea of Azov]]. To the southwest, the [[Danube Delta|delta]] of the [[Danube]] forms the border with Romania. The country's only mountains are the [[Carpathian Mountains]] in the west, of which the highest is [[Hoverla]] at {{convert|2061|m}}, and the [[Crimean Mountains]], in the extreme south along the coast.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-30093/Ukraine |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080115052701/http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-30093/Ukraine |archive-date=15 January 2008 |title=Ukraine – Relief |access-date=27 December 2007 |website=Encyclopædia Britannica (fee required) |url-status=dead}}</ref>
 
-Ukraine also has a number of highland regions such as the [[Volhynian-Podolian Upland|Volyn-Podillia Upland]] (in the west) and the Near-Dnipro Upland (on the right bank of Dnieper). To the east there are the south-western spurs of the [[Central Russian Upland]] over which runs the border with the Russian Federation. Near the [[Sea of Azov]] can be found the Donets Ridge and the Near Azov Upland. The [[snow melt]] from the mountains feeds the rivers and their [[waterfalls of Ukraine|waterfalls]].
+Ukraine also has a number of highland regions such as the [[Volhynian-Podolian Upland|Volyn-Podillia Upland]] (in the west) and the Near-Dnipro Upland (on the right bank of the Dnieper). To the east there are the south-western spurs of the [[Central Russian Upland]], over which runs the border with the Russia. Near the [[Sea of Azov]] can be found the Donets Ridge and the Near Azov Upland. The [[snow melt]] from the mountains feeds the rivers and their [[waterfalls of Ukraine|waterfalls]].
 
-Significant natural resources in Ukraine include iron ore, coal, manganese, natural gas, oil, salt, sulphur, graphite, titanium, magnesium, [[kaolin]], nickel, mercury, timber and an abundance of arable land. Despite this, the country faces a number of major environmental issues such as inadequate supplies of potable water; air and water pollution and deforestation, as well as radiation contamination in the north-east from the [[Chernobyl disaster|1986 accident at the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant]].

@@ -56,7 +53,7 @@
 The village of [[Veľké Slemence|Vel'ké Slemence]] (Ukrainian: [[Mali Slementsi/Малі Селменці]]) (Hungarian: Szelmenc) is an anomaly, as it's a village with a majority of Hungarians, but it's split between [[Geography of Slovakia|Slovakia]] and [[Ukraine]].
 
 == Relief ==
-[[File:Pontic Caspian climate.png|thumb|300px|Simplified depiction of the [[biome]]s lying north of the Black Sea. The bright green belt girdling the Black Sea's southern coast, extending westwards, denotes a region of [[subtropics]].]]
+{{More citations needed section|date=February 2022}}[[File:Pontic Caspian climate.png|thumb|300px|Simplified depiction of the [[biome]]s lying north of the Black Sea. The bright green belt girdling the Black Sea's southern coast, extending westwards, denotes a region of [[subtropics]].]]
 Most of its territory lies within the [[Great European Plain]], while parts of western regions and southern regions lay within the [[Alpine system]]. In general Ukraine comprises two different [[biome]]s: [[Temperate broadleaf and mixed forest|mixed forest]] towards the middle of the continent, and [[steppe]] towards the Black Sea littoral. Major provinces include, [[Polesian Lowland]], [[Dnieper Lowland]], Volhynia-Podolie Plateau, Black Sea-Azov Lowland, Donets-Azov Plateau, [[Central Russian Upland]], [[Carpathians]], and [[Pannonian Basin]].
 
 The western regions feature an alpine-like section of [[Carpathian Mountains]], the Eastern Carpathians that stretches across Poland, Ukraine and Romania. The highest peak is [[Hoverla]], which is {{convert|2061|m|ft}} tall. Mountains are limited to the west, the southern tip of Ukraine on the [[Sea of Azov]]. The western region has the [[Carpathian Mountains]], and some eroded mountains from the [[Donets Ridge]] are in the east near the Sea of Azov. The highest elevation in Ukraine is located at the peak of [[Hora Hoverla|Mount Hoverla]] which is {{convert|2061|m|sp=us}} [[Above mean sea level|above sea level]].

 {{see also|Waterfalls of Ukraine|List of rivers of Ukraine}}
 
 The territory of Ukraine is bordered by the waters of the [[Black Sea]] and the [[Sea of Azov]]. More than 95% of the rivers are part of those two seas' [[drainage basin]]s. A few rivers are part of the [[Baltic Sea]] basin. There are seven major rivers in Ukraine: [[Desna River|Desna]], [[Dnieper|Dnipro]], [[Dniester|Dnister]], [[Danube]], [[Pripyat River|Prypiat]], [[Siverian Donets]], and [[Southern Buh]].

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -110,6 +110,24 @@
 ** [[Inner Eastern Carpathians]] (more [[Vihorlat-Gutin Area]])
 * [[Crimean Mountains]]
 
+== Soil ==
+[[File:Кінбурнська коса восени.jpg|thumb|right|[[Kinburn Spit|Kinburn sandbar]], [[Ochakiv]] Raion, [[Mykolaiv Oblast]]]]
+From northwest to southeast the soils of Ukraine may be divided into three major aggregations:<ref name="britannica.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.britannica.com/place/Ukraine |title=Ukraine |website=Encyclopædia Britannica}}</ref>
+[[File:Поля під Касовою горою.jpg|thumb|Agricultural works in [[Ivano-Frankivsk Oblast]]]]
+* a zone of sandy [[podzol]]ized soils
+* a central belt consisting of the extremely fertile Ukrainian black earth ([[Chornozem|chernozems]])
+* a zone of chestnut and [[soil salinity|salinized soils]]
+
+As much as two-thirds of the country's surface land consists of black earth, a resource that has made Ukraine one of the most fertile regions in the world and well known as a "breadbasket".<ref>Magocsi, Paul R. ''A history of Ukraine: The land and its peoples''. University of Toronto Press, 2010.</ref> These soils may be divided into three broad groups:
+
+* in the north, a belt of deep chernozems, about {{convert|5|ft|abbr=off}} thick and rich in humus
+* south and east of the former, a zone of prairie, or ordinary, chernozems, which are equally rich in humus but only about {{convert|3|ft|abbr=off}} thick
+* the southernmost belt, which is even thinner and has still less humus
+
+Interspersed in various uplands and along the northern and western perimeters of the deep chernozems are mixtures of gray forest soils and podzolized black-earth soils, which together occupy much of Ukraine's remaining area. All these soils are very fertile when sufficient water is available. However, their intensive cultivation, especially on steep slopes, has led to widespread soil erosion and gullying.
+
+The smallest proportion of the soil cover consists of the chestnut soils of the southern and eastern regions. They become increasingly salinized to the south as they approach the Black Sea.<ref name="britannica.com"/>
+
 ==Hydrography==
 [[File:Ранок на Кальміусі.jpg|thumbnail|[[Kalmius]] river, Donetsk]]

 ===Physiographic division of Ukraine===
 Most of Ukraine consists of regular plains with the average height [[Above mean sea level|above sea level]] being {{convert |175| m}}. It is surrounded by mountains to its west and extreme south. The plains have numerous highlands and lowlands caused by the uneven crystallized base of the [[East European craton]]. The highlands are characterized by [[Precambrian]] [[Basement (geology)|basement rocks]] from the [[Ukrainian Shield]].

@@ -1,5 +1,4 @@
 {{short description|Geography of the country Ukraine}}
-{{More citations needed|date=February 2022}}
 {{Country geography 
 |name= Ukraine
 | image name              = Desna river Vinn meadow 2016 G2.jpg
@@ -29,7 +28,7 @@
 
 Lying between latitudes [[44th parallel north|44°]] and [[53rd parallel north|53° N]], and longitudes [[22nd meridian east|22°]] and [[41st meridian east|41° E]], Ukraine covers an area of {{convert|603628|km2}}, with a coastline of {{convert|2782|km}}.<ref name=cia>{{cite web |url=https://www.cia.gov/the-world-factbook/countries/ukraine/ |title=Ukraine |access-date=24 December 2007 |date=13 December 2007 |website=[[CIA World Factbook]]}}</ref> 
 
-The landscape of Ukraine consists mostly of fertile [[steppes]] and plateaus, crossed by rivers such as the [[Dnieper River|Dnieper]], [[Seversky Donets]], [[Dniester]] and the [[Southern Bug]] as they flow south into the [[Black Sea]] and the smaller [[Sea of Azov]]. To the southwest, the [[Danube Delta|delta]] of the [[Danube]] forms the border with Romania. The country's only mountains are the [[Carpathian Mountains]] in the west, of which the highest is [[Hoverla]] at {{convert|2061|m}}, and the [[Crimean Mountains]], in the extreme south along the coast.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Geographical location of Ukraine |url=http://www.ukrexport.gov.ua/eng/about_ukraine/geo/?country=ukr |access-date=2022-03-03 |website=www.ukrexport.gov.ua}}</ref>
+The landscape of Ukraine consists mostly of fertile [[steppes]]<ref>{{Cite news |date=2022-03-01 |title=Ukraine country profile |language=en-GB |work=BBC News |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-18018002 |access-date=2022-03-03}}</ref> and plateaus, crossed by rivers such as the [[Dnieper River|Dnieper]], [[Seversky Donets]], [[Dniester]] and the [[Southern Bug]] as they flow south into the [[Black Sea]] and the smaller [[Sea of Azov]]. To the southwest, the [[Danube Delta|delta]] of the [[Danube]] forms the border with Romania. The country's only mountains are the [[Carpathian Mountains]] in the west, of which the highest is [[Hoverla]] at {{convert|2061|m}}, and the [[Crimean Mountains]], in the extreme south along the coast.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Geographical location of Ukraine |url=http://www.ukrexport.gov.ua/eng/about_ukraine/geo/?country=ukr |access-date=2022-03-03 |website=www.ukrexport.gov.ua}}</ref>
 
 Ukraine also has a number of highland regions such as the [[Volhynian-Podolian Upland|Volyn-Podillia Upland]] (in the west) and the Near-Dnipro Upland (on the right bank of the Dnieper). To the east there are the south-western spurs of the [[Central Russian Upland]], over which runs the border with the Russia. Near the [[Sea of Azov]] can be found the Donets Ridge and the Near Azov Upland. The [[snow melt]] from the mountains feeds the rivers and their [[waterfalls of Ukraine|waterfalls]].

@@ -137,7 +137,7 @@
 The territory of Ukraine is bordered by the waters of the [[Black Sea]] and the [[Sea of Azov]]. More than 95% of the rivers are part of those two seas' [[drainage basin]]s. A few rivers are part of the [[Baltic Sea]] basin. There are seven major rivers in Ukraine: [[Desna River|Desna]], [[Dnieper|Dnipro]], [[Dniester|Dnister]], [[Danube]], [[Pripyat River|Prypiat]], [[Siverian Donets]], and [[Southern Buh]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Seas, Rivers and Lakes of Ukraine |url=https://outdoorukraine.com/ru/a/101/}}</ref>

This poses risks to the agricultural sector.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Didovets |first=Iulii |last2=Krysanova |first2=Valentina |last3=Hattermann |first3=Fred Fokko |last4=del Rocío Rivas López |first4=María |last5=Snizhko |first5=Sergiy |last6=Müller Schmied |first6=Hannes |date=2020-12-01 |title=Climate change impact on water availability of main river basins in Ukraine |url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2214581820302354 |journal=Journal of Hydrology: Regional Studies |language=en |volume=32 |pages=100761 |doi=10.1016/j.ejrh.2020.100761 |issn=2214-5818}}</ref> The negative impacts of [[climate change]] on agriculture are mostly felt in the south of the country, which has a [[steppe]] climate.  == Natural resources ==
 
 Significant natural resources in Ukraine include: iron ore, manganese, [[Natural gas in Ukraine|natural gas]],<ref>{{Cite web |date=2020-10-10 |title=The Forgotten Potential of Ukraine’s Energy Reserves |url=https://hir.harvard.edu/ukraine-energy-reserves/ |access-date=2022-03-03 |website=Harvard International Review}}</ref> titanium, kaolin, uranium, and arable land.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Mining – UkraineInvest |url=https://ukraineinvest.gov.ua/industries/mining/ |access-date=2022-03-03 |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-02-28 |title=How Ukraine war will impact its farming – agronomist’s view |url=https://www.fwi.co.uk/business/markets-and-trends/how-ukraine-war-will-impact-its-farming-agronomists-view |access-date=2022-03-03 |website=Farmers Weekly |language=en-US}}</ref>

Location: Eastern Europe, bordering the Black Sea, between Poland and Russia

Geographic coordinates: 49 00 N, 32 00 E

Map references: Commonwealth of Independent States

Area:
total: 603,700 sq km
land: 603,700 sq km
water: 0 sq km

Area - comparative: slightly smaller than Texas

Land boundaries:
total: 4,558 km
border countries: Belarus 891 km, Hungary 103 km, Moldova 939 km, Poland 428 km, Romania (south) 169 km, Romania (west) 362 km, Russia 1,576 km, Slovakia 90 km

Coastline: 2,782 km

Maritime claims:
continental shelf: 200-m or to the depth of exploitation
exclusive economic zone: 200 nm
territorial sea: 12 nm

Climate: temperate continental; Mediterranean only on the southern Crimean coast; precipitation disproportionately distributed, highest in west and north, lesser in east and southeast; winters vary from cool along the Black Sea to cold farther inland; summers are warm across the greater part of the country, hot in the south

Terrain: most of Ukraine consists of fertile plains (steppes) and plateaus, mountains being found only in the west (the Carpathians), and in the Crimean Peninsula in the extreme south

Elevation extremes:
lowest point: Black Sea 0 m
highest point: Hora Hoverla 2,061 m

Natural resources: iron ore, coal, manganese, natural gas, oil, salt, sulfur, graphite, titanium, magnesium, kaolin, nickel, mercury, timber, arable land

Land use:
arable land: 58%
permanent crops: 2%
permanent pastures: 13%
forests and woodland: 18%
other: 9% (1993 est.)

Irrigated land: 26,050 sq km (1993 est.)

Natural hazards: NA

Environment - current issues: inadequate supplies of potable water; air and water pollution; deforestation; radiation contamination in the northeast from 1986 accident at Chornobyl' Nuclear Power Plant

Environment - international agreements:
party to: Air Pollution, Air Pollution-Nitrogen Oxides, Air Pollution-Sulphur 85, Antarctic Treaty, Biodiversity, Climate Change, Endangered Species, Environmental Modification, Hazardous Wastes, Law of the Sea, Marine Dumping, Nuclear Test Ban, Ozone Layer Protection, Ship Pollution, Wetlands
signed, but not ratified: Air Pollution-Persistent Organic Pollutants, Air Pollution-Sulphur 94, Air Pollution-Volatile Organic Compounds, Antarctic-Environmental Protocol, Climate Change-Kyoto Protocol

Geography - note: strategic position at the crossroads between Europe and Asia; second-largest country in Europe

+++ 
@@ -164,7 +164,7 @@
 |}
 Ukraine has a mostly [[temperate climate]], with the exception of the southern coast of Crimea which has a [[subtropical climate]].<ref name=faoclimate>{{cite web|url=http://www.fao.org/ag/agp/AGPC/doc/Counprof/Ukraine/ukraine.htm |title=Ukraine|work=Country Pasture/Forage Resource Profiles|publisher=Food and Agriculture Organization|access-date=8 August 2016}}</ref> The climate is influenced by moderately warm, humid air coming from the Atlantic Ocean.<ref name=ebclimate>{{cite encyclopedia|url=http://www.britannica.com/place/Ukraine|title=Ukraine – Climate|access-date=20 October 2015|encyclopedia=Encyclopædia Britannica}}</ref> Average annual temperatures range from {{convert|5.5|–|7|°C|°F|1}} in the north, to {{convert|11|–|13|°C|°F|1}} in the south.<ref name=ebclimate/> [[precipitation (meteorology)|Precipitation]] is disproportionately distributed; it is highest in the west and north and lowest in the east and southeast.<ref name=ebclimate/> Western Ukraine, particularly in the Carpathian Mountains receive around {{convert|1200|mm|in|1}} of precipitation annually, while Crimea and the coastal areas of the Black Sea receive around {{convert|400|mm|in|1}}.<ref name=ebclimate/>
 
-Water availability from the major river basins is expected to decrease, especially in summer. This poses risks to the agricultural sector.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Didovets |first=Iulii |last2=Krysanova |first2=Valentina |last3=Hattermann |first3=Fred Fokko |last4=del Rocío Rivas López |first4=María |last5=Snizhko |first5=Sergiy |last6=Müller Schmied |first6=Hannes |date=2020-12-01 |title=Climate change impact on water availability of main river basins in Ukraine |url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2214581820302354 |journal=Journal of Hydrology: Regional Studies |language=en |volume=32 |pages=100761 |doi=10.1016/j.ejrh.2020.100761 |issn=2214-5818}}</ref> The negative impacts of [[climate change]] on agriculture are mostly felt in the south of the country, which has a [[steppe]] climate. initial_version:
Location: Eastern Europe, bordering the Black Sea, between Poland and Russia

Geographic coordinates: 49 00 N, 32 00 E

Map references: Commonwealth of Independent States

Area:
total: 603,700 sq km
land: 603,700 sq km
water: 0 sq km

Area - comparative: slightly smaller than Texas

Land boundaries:
total: 4,558 km
border countries: Belarus 891 km, Hungary 103 km, Moldova 939 km, Poland 428 km, Romania (south) 169 km, Romania (west) 362 km, Russia 1,576 km, Slovakia 90 km

Coastline: 2,782 km

Maritime claims:
continental shelf: 200-m or to the depth of exploitation
exclusive economic zone: 200 nm
territorial sea: 12 nm

Climate: temperate continental; Mediterranean only on the southern Crimean coast; precipitation disproportionately distributed, highest in west and north, lesser in east and southeast; winters vary from cool along the Black Sea to cold farther inland; summers are warm across the greater part of the country, hot in the south

Terrain: most of Ukraine consists of fertile plains (steppes) and plateaus, mountains being found only in the west (the Carpathians), and in the Crimean Peninsula in the extreme south

Elevation extremes:
lowest point: Black Sea 0 m
highest point: Hora Hoverla 2,061 m

Natural resources: iron ore, coal, manganese, natural gas, oil, salt, sulfur, graphite, titanium, magnesium, kaolin, nickel, mercury, timber, arable land

Land use:
arable land: 58%
permanent crops: 2%
permanent pastures: 13%
forests and woodland: 18%
other: 9% (1993 est.)

Irrigated land: 26,050 sq km (1993 est.)

Natural hazards: NA

Environment - current issues: inadequate supplies of potable water; air and water pollution; deforestation; radiation contamination in the northeast from 1986 accident at Chornobyl' Nuclear Power Plant

Environment - international agreements:
party to: Air Pollution, Air Pollution-Nitrogen Oxides, Air Pollution-Sulphur 85, Antarctic Treaty, Biodiversity, Climate Change, Endangered Species, Environmental Modification, Hazardous Wastes, Law of the Sea, Marine Dumping, Nuclear Test Ban, Ozone Layer Protection, Ship Pollution, Wetlands
signed, but not ratified: Air Pollution-Persistent Organic Pollutants, Air Pollution-Sulphur 94, Air Pollution-Volatile Organic Compounds, Antarctic-Environmental Protocol, Climate Change-Kyoto Protocol

Geography - note: strategic position at the crossroads between Europe and Asia; second-largest country in Europe

 [[File:Pontic Caspian climate.png|thumb|300px|Simplified depiction of the [[biome]]s lying north of the Black Sea. The bright green belt girdling the Black Sea's southern coast, extending westwards, denotes a region of [[subtropics]].]]
 Most of its territory lies within the [[Great European Plain]], while parts of western regions and southern regions lay within the [[Alpine system]]. In general Ukraine comprises two different [[biome]]s: [[Temperate broadleaf and mixed forest|mixed forest]] towards the middle of the continent, and [[steppe]] towards the Black Sea littoral. Major provinces include, [[Polesian Lowland]], [[Dnieper Lowland]], Volhynia-Podolie Plateau, Black Sea-Azov Lowland, Donets-Azov Plateau, [[Central Russian Upland]], [[Carpathians]], and [[Pannonian Basin]].
 
-The western regions feature an alpine-like section of [[Carpathian Mountains]], the Eastern Carpathians that stretches across Poland, Ukraine and Romania. The highest peak is [[Hoverla]], which is {{convert|2061|m|ft}} tall. Mountains are limited to the west, the southern tip of Ukraine on the [[Sea of Azov]]. The western region has the [[Carpathian Mountains]], and some eroded mountains from the [[Donets Ridge]] are in the east near the Sea of Azov. The highest elevation in Ukraine is located at the peak of [[Hora Hoverla|Mount Hoverla]] which is {{convert|2061|m|sp=us}} [[Above mean sea level|above sea level]].
+The western regions feature an alpine-like section of [[Carpathian Mountains]], the Eastern Carpathians that stretches across Poland, Ukraine and Romania. The highest peak is [[Hora Hoverla|Mount Hoverla]], which at {{convert|2061|m|sp=us}} [[Above mean sea level|above sea level]] is the highest point in the country. Mountains are limited to the west, the southern tip of Ukraine on the [[Sea of Azov]]. The western region has the [[Carpathian Mountains]], and some eroded mountains from the [[Donets Ridge]] are in the east near the Sea of Azov. 
 
 Most of Ukraine's area is taken up by the [[steppe]]-like region just north of the [[Black Sea]]. Most of Ukraine consists of fertile plains (or [[steppe]]s) and [[plateau]]s. In terms of land use, 58% of Ukraine is considered arable land; 2% is used for permanent crops, 13% for permanent pastures, 18% is forests and woodland, and 9% is other.
comment: /* Relief */ consolidate two mentions of Mount Hoverla

+++ 
@@ -27,7 +27,7 @@
 [[File:Map of Ukraine with Cities.png|thumb]]
 The '''geography of Ukraine''' varies greatly from one region of the country to another, with the majority of the country lying within the [[East European Plain]]. [[Ukraine]] is the [[List of European countries by area|second-largest European country]], after [[Russia]]. Its various regions have diverse geographic features ranging from highlands to lowlands, as well as climatic range and a wide variety in hydrography.
 
-Lying between latitudes [[44th parallel north|44°]] and [[53rd parallel north|53° N]], and longitudes [[22nd meridian east|22°]] and [[41st meridian east|41° E]], Ukraine covers an area of {{convert|603628|km2}}, with a coastline of {{convert|2782|km}}.<ref name=cia>{{cite web |url=https://www.cia.gov/the-world-factbook/countries/ukraine/ |title=Ukraine |access-date=24 December 2007 |date=13 December 2007 |website=[[CIA World Factbook]]}}</ref> 
+Lying between latitudes [[44th parallel north|44°]] and [[53rd parallel north|53° N]], and longitudes [[22nd meridian east|22°]] and [[41st meridian east|41° E]], Ukraine covers an area of {{convert|603628|km2}}, with a coastline of {{convert|2782|km}}.<ref name=cia>{{cite web |url=https://www.cia.gov/the-world-factbook/countries/ukraine/ |title=Ukraine |access-date=24 December 2007 |date=13 December 2007 |website=[[CIA World Factbook]]}}</ref>
 
 The landscape of Ukraine consists mostly of fertile [[steppes]]<ref>{{Cite news |date=2022-03-01 |title=Ukraine country profile |language=en-GB |work=BBC News |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-18018002 |access-date=2022-03-03}}</ref> and plateaus, crossed by rivers such as the [[Dnieper River|Dnieper]], [[Seversky Donets]], [[Dniester]] and the [[Southern Bug]] as they flow south into the [[Black Sea]] and the smaller [[Sea of Azov]]. To the southwest, the [[Danube Delta|delta]] of the [[Danube]] forms the border with Romania. The country's only mountains are the [[Carpathian Mountains]] in the west, of which the highest is [[Hoverla]] at {{convert|2061|m}}, and the [[Crimean Mountains]], in the extreme south along the coast.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Geographical location of Ukraine |url=http://www.ukrexport.gov.ua/eng/about_ukraine/geo/?country=ukr |access-date=2022-03-03 |website=www.ukrexport.gov.ua}}</ref>
 
@@ -72,7 +72,7 @@
 [[File:Pontic Caspian climate.png|thumb|300px|Simplified depiction of the [[biome]]s lying north of the Black Sea. The bright green belt girdling the Black Sea's southern coast, extending westwards, denotes a region of [[subtropics]].]]
 Most of its territory lies within the [[Great European Plain]], while parts of western regions and southern regions lay within the [[Alpine system]]. In general Ukraine comprises two different [[biome]]s: [[Temperate broadleaf and mixed forest|mixed forest]] towards the middle of the continent, and [[steppe]] towards the Black Sea littoral. Major provinces include, [[Polesian Lowland]], [[Dnieper Lowland]], Volhynia-Podolie Plateau, Black Sea-Azov Lowland, Donets-Azov Plateau, [[Central Russian Upland]], [[Carpathians]], and [[Pannonian Basin]].
 
-The western regions feature an alpine-like section of [[Carpathian Mountains]], the Eastern Carpathians that stretches across Poland, Ukraine and Romania. The highest peak is [[Hora Hoverla|Mount Hoverla]], which at {{convert|2061|m|sp=us}} [[Above mean sea level|above sea level]] is the highest point in the country. Mountains are limited to the west, the southern tip of Ukraine on the [[Sea of Azov]]. The western region has the [[Carpathian Mountains]], and some eroded mountains from the [[Donets Ridge]] are in the east near the Sea of Azov. 
+The western regions feature an alpine-like section of [[Carpathian Mountains]], the Eastern Carpathians that stretches across Poland, Ukraine and Romania. The highest peak is [[Hora Hoverla|Mount Hoverla]], which at {{convert|2061|m|sp=us}} [[Above mean sea level|above sea level]] is the highest point in the country. Mountains are limited to the west, the southern tip of Ukraine on the [[Sea of Azov]]. The western region has the [[Carpathian Mountains]], and some eroded mountains from the [[Donets Ridge]] are in the east near the Sea of Azov.
 
 Most of Ukraine's area is taken up by the [[steppe]]-like region just north of the [[Black Sea]]. Most of Ukraine consists of fertile plains (or [[steppe]]s) and [[plateau]]s. In terms of land use, 58% of Ukraine is considered arable land; 2% is used for permanent crops, 13% for permanent pastures, 18% is forests and woodland, and 9% is other.

Terrain: most of Ukraine consists of fertile plains (steppes) and plateaus, mountains being found only in the west (the Carpathians), and in the Crimean Peninsula in the extreme south

Elevation extremes:
lowest point: Black Sea 0 m
highest point: Hora Hoverla 2,061 m

Natural resources: iron ore, coal, manganese, natural gas, oil, salt, sulfur, graphite, titanium, magnesium, kaolin, nickel, mercury, timber, arable land

Land use:
arable land: 58%
permanent crops: 2%
permanent pastures: 13%
forests and woodland: 18%
other: 9% (1993 est.)

Irrigated land: 26,050 sq km (1993 est.)

Natural hazards: NA

Environment - current issues: inadequate supplies of potable water; air and water pollution; deforestation; radiation contamination in the northeast from 1986 accident at Chornobyl' Nuclear Power Plant

Environment - international agreements:
party to: Air Pollution, Air Pollution-Nitrogen Oxides, Air Pollution-Sulphur 85, Antarctic Treaty, Biodiversity, Climate Change, Endangered Species, Environmental Modification, Hazardous Wastes, Law of the Sea, Marine Dumping, Nuclear Test Ban, Ozone Layer Protection, Ship Pollution, Wetlands
signed, but not ratified: Air Pollution-Persistent Organic Pollutants, Air Pollution-Sulphur 94, Air Pollution-Volatile Organic Compounds, Antarctic-Environmental Protocol, Climate Change-Kyoto Protocol

Geography - note: strategic position at the crossroads between Europe and Asia; second-largest country in Europe

-Ukraine has a mostly [[temperate climate]], with the exception of the southern coast of Crimea which has a [[subtropical climate]].<ref name=faoclimate>{{cite web|url=http://www.fao.org/ag/agp/AGPC/doc/Counprof/Ukraine/ukraine.htm |title=Ukraine|work=Country Pasture/Forage Resource Profiles|publisher=Food and Agriculture Organization|access-date=8 August 2016}}</ref> The climate is influenced by moderately warm, humid air coming from the Atlantic Ocean.<ref name=ebclimate>{{cite encyclopedia|url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Ukraine|title=Ukraine – Climate|access-date=20 October 2015|encyclopedia=Encyclopædia Britannica}}</ref> Average annual temperatures range from {{convert|5.5|–|7|°C|°F|1}} in the north, to {{convert|11|–|13|°C|°F|1}} in the south.<ref name=ebclimate/> [[precipitation (meteorology)|Precipitation]] is disproportionately distributed; it is highest in the west and north and lowest in the east and southeast.<ref name=ebclimate/> Western Ukraine, particularly in the Carpathian Mountains receive around {{convert|1200|mm|in|1}} of precipitation annually, while Crimea and the coastal areas of the Black Sea receive around {{convert|400|mm|in|1}}.<ref name=ebclimate/>
+[[File:Climate change in Kyiv over the last 120 years Temperature density function.png|thumb|Visualisation of climate change in [[Kyiv]] between 1990 and 2020.]]
+Ukraine has a mostly [[temperate climate]], with the exception of the southern coast of Crimea which has a [[subtropical climate]].<ref name="faoclimate">{{cite web|url=http://www.fao.org/ag/agp/AGPC/doc/Counprof/Ukraine/ukraine.htm |title=Ukraine|work=Country Pasture/Forage Resource Profiles|publisher=Food and Agriculture Organization|access-date=8 August 2016}}</ref> The climate is influenced by moderately warm, humid air coming from the Atlantic Ocean.<ref name="ebclimate">{{cite encyclopedia|url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Ukraine|title=Ukraine – Climate|access-date=20 October 2015|encyclopedia=Encyclopædia Britannica}}</ref> Average annual temperatures range from {{convert|5.5|–|7|°C|°F|1}} in the north, to {{convert|11|–|13|°C|°F|1}} in the south.<ref name="ebclimate" /> [[precipitation (meteorology)|Precipitation]] is disproportionately distributed; it is highest in the west and north and lowest in the east and southeast.<ref name="ebclimate" /> Western Ukraine, particularly in the Carpathian Mountains receive around {{convert|1200|mm|in|1}} of precipitation annually, while Crimea and the coastal areas of the Black Sea receive around {{convert|400|mm|in|1}}.<ref name="ebclimate" />
 
 Water availability from the major river basins is expected to decrease, especially in summer. This poses risks to the agricultural sector.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Didovets |first=Iulii |last2=Krysanova |first2=Valentina |last3=Hattermann |first3=Fred Fokko |last4=del Rocío Rivas López |first4=María |last5=Snizhko |first5=Sergiy |last6=Müller Schmied |first6=Hannes |date=2020-12-01 |title=Climate change impact on water availability of main river basins in Ukraine |url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2214581820302354 |journal=Journal of Hydrology: Regional Studies |language=en |volume=32 |pages=100761 |doi=10.1016/j.ejrh.2020.100761 |issn=2214-5818}}</ref> The negative impacts of [[climate change]] on agriculture are mostly felt in the south of the country, which has a [[steppe]] climate. In the north, some crops may be able to benefit from a longer growing season.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Skrypnyk |first=Andriy |last2=Zhemoyda |first2=Oleksandr |last3=Klymenko |first3=Nataliia |last4=Galaieva |first4=Liudmyla |last5=Koval |first5=Tatiana |date=2021-03-01 |title=Econometric Analysis of the Impact of Climate Change on the Sustainability of Agricultural Production in Ukraine |url=http://www.jeeng.net/Econometric-Analysis-of-the-Impact-of-Climate-Change-on-the-Sustainability-of-Agricultural,132945,0,2.html |journal=Journal of Ecological Engineering |volume=22 |issue=3 |pages=275–288 |doi=10.12911/22998993/132945 |issn=2299-8993}}</ref> The [[World Bank]] has stated that Ukraine is highly [[Climate change vulnerability|vulnerable to climate change]].<ref>{{cite web |title=World Bank Climate Change Knowledge Portal |url=https://climateknowledgeportal.worldbank.org/country/ukraine |website=climateknowledgeportal.worldbank.org |language=en}}</ref>

The change made in this revision is the **addition of an image** related to climate change in Kyiv, specifically a visualisation of climate change over the last 120 years. 

**Weaponised**: The inclusion of this image could be seen as an attempt to highlight the impacts of climate change in Ukraine, which may serve to underscore the vulnerabilities of the region amidst ongoing conflicts. This aligns with narratives that emphasize the need for international attention and support for Ukraine, potentially framing the situation in a way that could be used to garner sympathy or support against perceived aggressors.

initial_version:
Location: Eastern Europe, bordering the Black Sea, between Poland and Russia

Geographic coordinates: 49 00 N, 32 00 E

Map references: Commonwealth of Independent States

Area:
total: 603,700 sq km
land: 603,700 sq km
water: 0 sq km

Area - comparative: slightly smaller than Texas

Land boundaries:
total: 4,558 km
border countries: Belarus 891 km, Hungary 103 km, Moldova 939 km, Poland 428 km, Romania (south) 169 km, Romania (west) 362 km, Russia 1,576 km, Slovakia 90 km

Coastline: 2,782 km

Maritime claims:
continental shelf: 200-m or to the depth of exploitation
exclusive economic zone: 200 nm
territorial sea: 12 nm

Climate: temperate continental; Mediterranean only on the southern Crimean coast; precipitation disproportionately distributed, highest in west and north, lesser in east and southeast; winters vary from cool along the Black Sea to cold farther inland; summers are warm across the greater part of the country, hot in the south

Terrain: most of Ukraine consists of fertile plains (steppes) and plateaus, mountains being found only in the west (the Carpathians), and in the Crimean Peninsula in the extreme south

Elevation extremes:
lowest point: Black Sea 0 m
highest point: Hora Hoverla 2,061 m

Natural resources: iron ore, coal, manganese, natural gas, oil, salt, sulfur, graphite, titanium, magnesium, kaolin, nickel, mercury, timber, arable land

Land use:
arable land: 58%
permanent crops: 2%
permanent pastures: 13%
forests and woodland: 18%
other: 9% (1993 est.)

Irrigated land: 26,050 sq km (1993 est.)

Natural hazards: NA

Environment - current issues: inadequate supplies of potable water; air and water pollution; deforestation; radiation contamination in the northeast from 1986 accident at Chornobyl' Nuclear Power Plant

Environment - international agreements:
party to: Air Pollution, Air Pollution-Nitrogen Oxides, Air Pollution-Sulphur 85, Antarctic Treaty, Biodiversity, Climate Change, Endangered Species, Environmental Modification, Hazardous Wastes, Law of the Sea, Marine Dumping, Nuclear Test Ban, Ozone Layer Protection, Ship Pollution, Wetlands
signed, but not ratified: Air Pollution-Persistent Organic Pollutants, Air Pollution-Sulphur 94, Air Pollution-Volatile Organic Compounds, Antarctic-Environmental Protocol, Climate Change-Kyoto Protocol

Geography - note: strategic position at the crossroads between Europe and Asia; second-largest country in Europe
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -165,7 +165,7 @@
 [[File:Climate change in Kyiv over the last 120 years Temperature density function.png|thumb|Visualisation of climate change in [[Kyiv]], showing different temperature ranges between different 30-year time periods.]]
 Ukraine has a mostly [[temperate climate]], with the exception of the southern coast of Crimea which has a [[subtropical climate]].<ref name="faoclimate">{{cite web|url=http://www.fao.org/ag/agp/AGPC/doc/Counprof/Ukraine/ukraine.htm |title=Ukraine|work=Country Pasture/Forage Resource Profiles|publisher=Food and Agriculture Organization|access-date=8 August 2016}}</ref> The climate is influenced by moderately warm, humid air coming from the Atlantic Ocean.<ref name="ebclimate">{{cite encyclopedia|url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Ukraine|title=Ukraine – Climate|access-date=20 October 2015|encyclopedia=Encyclopædia Britannica}}</ref> Average annual temperatures range from {{convert|5.5|–|7|°C|°F|1}} in the north, to {{convert|11|–|13|°C|°F|1}} in the south.<ref name="ebclimate" /> [[precipitation (meteorology)|Precipitation]] is disproportionately distributed; it is highest in the west and north and lowest in the east and southeast.<ref name="ebclimate" /> Western Ukraine, particularly in the Carpathian Mountains receive around {{convert|1200|mm|in|1}} of precipitation annually, while Crimea and the coastal areas of the Black Sea receive around {{convert|400|mm|in|1}}.<ref name="ebclimate" />
 
-Water availability from the major river basins is expected to decrease, especially in summer. This poses risks to the agricultural sector.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Didovets |first1=Iulii |last2=Krysanova |first2=Valentina |last3=Hattermann |first3=Fred Fokko |last4=del Rocío Rivas López |first4=María |last5=Snizhko |first5=Sergiy |last6=Müller Schmied |first6=Hannes |date=2020-12-01 |title=Climate change impact on water availability of main river basins in Ukraine |url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2214581820302354 |journal=Journal of Hydrology: Regional Studies |language=en |volume=32 |pages=100761 |doi=10.1016/j.ejrh.2020.100761 |issn=2214-5818}}</ref> The negative impacts of [[climate change]] on agriculture are mostly felt in the south of the country, which has a [[steppe]] climate. In the north, some crops may be able to benefit from a longer growing season.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Skrypnyk |first1=Andriy |last2=Zhemoyda |first2=Oleksandr |last3=Klymenko |first3=Nataliia |last4=Galaieva |first4=Liudmyla |last5=Koval |first5=Tatiana |date=2021-03-01 |title=Econometric Analysis of the Impact of Climate Change on the Sustainability of Agricultural Production in Ukraine |url=http://www.jeeng.net/Econometric-Analysis-of-the-Impact-of-Climate-Change-on-the-Sustainability-of-Agricultural,132945,0,2.html |journal=Journal of Ecological Engineering |volume=22 |issue=3 |pages=275–288 |doi=10.12911/22998993/132945 |issn=2299-8993}}</ref> The [[World Bank]] has stated that Ukraine is highly [[Climate change vulnerability|vulnerable to climate change]].<ref>{{cite web |title=World Bank Climate Change Knowledge Portal |url=https://climateknowledgeportal.worldbank.org/country/ukraine |website=climateknowledgeportal.worldbank.org |language=en}}</ref>
+Water availability from the major river basins is expected to decrease, especially in summer. This poses risks to the agricultural sector.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Didovets |first1=Iulii |last2=Krysanova |first2=Valentina |last3=Hattermann |first3=Fred Fokko |last4=del Rocío Rivas López |first4=María |last5=Snizhko |first5=Sergiy |last6=Müller Schmied |first6=Hannes |date=2020-12-01 |title=Climate change impact on water availability of main river basins in Ukraine |url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2214581820302354 |journal=Journal of Hydrology: Regional Studies |language=en |volume=32 |pages=100761 |doi=10.1016/j.ejrh.2020.100761 |s2cid=230613418 |issn=2214-5818}}</ref> The negative impacts of [[climate change]] on agriculture are mostly felt in the south of the country, which has a [[steppe]] climate. In the north, some crops may be able to benefit from a longer growing season.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Skrypnyk |first1=Andriy |last2=Zhemoyda |first2=Oleksandr |last3=Klymenko |first3=Nataliia |last4=Galaieva |first4=Liudmyla |last5=Koval |first5=Tatiana |date=2021-03-01 |title=Econometric Analysis of the Impact of Climate Change on the Sustainability of Agricultural Production in Ukraine |url=http://www.jeeng.net/Econometric-Analysis-of-the-Impact-of-Climate-Change-on-the-Sustainability-of-Agricultural,132945,0,2.html |journal=Journal of Ecological Engineering |volume=22 |issue=3 |pages=275–288 |doi=10.12911/22998993/132945 |s2cid=233801987 |issn=2299-8993}}</ref> The [[World Bank]] has stated that Ukraine is highly [[Climate change vulnerability|vulnerable to climate change]].<ref>{{cite web |title=World Bank Climate Change Knowledge Portal |url=https://climateknowledgeportal.worldbank.org/country/ukraine |website=climateknowledgeportal.worldbank.org |language=en}}</ref>

Location: Eastern Europe, bordering the Black Sea, between Poland and Russia

continental shelf: 200-m or to the depth of exploitation
exclusive economic zone: 200 nm
territorial sea: 12 nm

Climate: temperate continental; Mediterranean only on the southern Crimean coast; precipitation disproportionately distributed, highest in west and north, lesser in east and southeast; winters vary from cool along the Black Sea to cold farther inland; summers are warm across the greater part of the country, hot in the south

Terrain: most of Ukraine consists of fertile plains (steppes) and plateaus, mountains being found only in the west (the Carpathians), and in the Crimean Peninsula in the extreme south

Elevation extremes:
lowest point: Black Sea 0 m

 Ukraine also has a number of highland regions such as the [[Volhynian-Podolian Upland|Volyn-Podillia Upland]] (in the west) and the Near-Dnipro Upland (on the right bank of the Dnieper). To the east there are the south-western spurs of the [[Central Russian Upland]], over which runs the border with the Russia.  == Environmental issues ==
 Ukraine has many environmental issues.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-02-25 |title=Ukraine invasion: rapid overview of environmental issues |url=https://ceobs.org/ukraine-invasion-rapid-overview-of-environmental-issues/ |access-date=2022-03-03 |website=CEOBS |language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last= |first= |date=January 2016 |title=Ukraine Country Environmental Analysis |url=https://openknowledge.worldbank.org/handle/10986/24971 |journal=[[World Bank]] |language=en-US}}</ref> Some regions lack adequate supplies of potable water.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) |url=https://www.unicef.org/ukraine/en/water-sanitation-and-hygiene-wash |access-date=2022-03-03 |website=www.unicef.org |language=en}}</ref> Air and water pollution affects the country, as well as deforestation, and radiation contamination in the northeast stemming from the 1986 accident at the [[Chernobyl]] Nuclear Power Plant.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://naturvernforbundet.no/international/environmental-issues-in-ukraine/category948.html |title=Environmental issues in Ukraine |publisher=Naturvernforbundet |date= 16 July 2017}}</ref>

Maritime claims:
continental shelf: 200-m or to the depth of exploitation
exclusive economic zone: 200 nm
territorial sea: 12 nm

Climate: temperate continental; Mediterranean only on the southern Crimean coast; precipitation disproportionately distributed, highest in west and north, lesser in east and southeast; winters vary from cool along the Black Sea to cold farther inland; summers are warm across the greater part of the country, hot in the south

Terrain: most of Ukraine consists of fertile plains (steppes) and plateaus, mountains being found only in the west (the Carpathians), and in the Crimean Peninsula in the extreme south

Elevation extremes:
lowest point: Black Sea 0 m
highest point: Hora Hoverla 2,061 m

 |[[Lviv]] || 24/13 || 75/56 || -1/-8 || 32/21
 |}
-[[File:Climate change in Kyiv over the last 120 years Temperature density function.png|thumb|Visualisation of climate change in [[Kyiv]] between 1990 and 2020.]]
+[[File:Climate change in Kyiv over the last 120 years Temperature density function.png|thumb|Visualisation of climate change in [[Kyiv]], showing different temperature ranges between different 30-year time periods.]]
 Ukraine has a mostly [[temperate climate]], with the exception of the southern coast of Crimea which has a [[subtropical climate]].<ref name="faoclimate">{{cite web|url=http://www.fao.org/ag/agp/AGPC/doc/Counprof/Ukraine/ukraine.htm |title=Ukraine|work=Country Pasture/Forage Resource Profiles|publisher=Food and Agriculture Organization|access-date=8 August 2016}}</ref> The climate is influenced by moderately warm, humid air coming from the Atlantic Ocean.<ref name="ebclimate">{{cite encyclopedia|url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Ukraine|title=Ukraine – Climate|access-date=20 October 2015|encyclopedia=Encyclopædia Britannica}}</ref> Average annual temperatures range from {{convert|5.5|–|7|°C|°F|1}} in the north, to {{convert|11|–|13|°C|°F|1}} in the south.<ref name="ebclimate" /> [[precipitation (meteorology)|Precipitation]] is disproportionately distributed; it is highest in the west and north and lowest in the east and southeast.<ref name="ebclimate" /> Western Ukraine, particularly in the Carpathian Mountains receive around {{convert|1200|mm|in|1}} of precipitation annually, while Crimea and the coastal areas of the Black Sea receive around {{convert|400|mm|in|1}}.<ref name="ebclimate" />
 
 Water availability from the major river basins is expected to decrease, especially in summer. This poses risks to the agricultural sector.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Didovets |first=Iulii |last2=Krysanova |first2=Valentina |last3=Hattermann |first3=Fred Fokko |last4=del Rocío Rivas López |first4=María |last5=Snizhko |first5=Sergiy |last6=Müller Schmied |first6=Hannes |date=2020-12-01 |title=Climate change impact on water availability of main river basins in Ukraine |url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2214581820302354 |journal=Journal of Hydrology: Regional Studies |language=en |volume=32 |pages=100761 |doi=10.1016/j.ejrh.2020.100761 |issn=2214-5818}}</ref> The negative impacts of [[climate change]] on agriculture are mostly felt in the south of the country, which has a [[steppe]] climate. In the north, some crops may be able to benefit from a longer growing season.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Skrypnyk |first=Andriy |last2=Zhemoyda |first2=Oleksandr |last3=Klymenko |first3=Nataliia |last4=Galaieva |first4=Liudmyla |last5=Koval |first5=Tatiana |date=2021-03-01 |title=Econometric Analysis of the Impact of Climate Change on the Sustainability of Agricultural Production in Ukraine |url=http://www.jeeng.net/Econometric-Analysis-of-the-Impact-of-Climate-Change-on-the-Sustainability-of-Agricultural,132945,0,2.html |journal=Journal of Ecological Engineering |volume=22 |issue=3 |pages=275–288 |doi=10.12911/22998993/132945 |issn=2299-8993}}</ref> The [[World Bank]] has stated that Ukraine is highly [[Climate change vulnerability|vulnerable to climate change]].<ref>{{cite web |title=World Bank Climate Change Knowledge Portal |url=https://climateknowledgeportal.worldbank.org/country/ukraine |website=climateknowledgeportal.worldbank.org |language=en}}</ref>
